movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Liz Tuccillo puts viewers nose to nose with her characters, and their discomfort feels visceral.
All Relative requires a strenuous suspension of disbelief.
Visually rich and heartwarming ...
What truly sets Captain Phillips apart from other high seas, high stakes adventures is a career-best performance from Hanks as Richard Phillips.
The absolute antithesis to the pioneering punk spirit it tries to portray.
Fellowes' many changes and additions diminish the power of Shakespeare's story.
Lacks the fresh, zingy immediacy of Diablo Cody's other works.
This is as plain-faced a film about slavery could possibly be, and the effect of its evenness is, oddly enough, more emotion.
The only joy is in a horrified desire to see what craziness happens next.
As predictable and uncomfortable as it can be, it's an assured crowd-pleaser.
A more than worthy (and weird) holiday diversion for the whole family.
Tries to humanize its leading lady, but it only embarrasses her (and us) in the process. Diana deserves so much more than this.
An inelegant misfire, this is a chink in Marvel's otherwise solid armor.
An admirably adult holiday feature that doesn't balk at real feelings.
Earmarked as a masterpiece, but it doesn't fully deliver on its promise.
While Russell's film succeeds on the strength of its casting and characters, it's dragged down by a murky and poorly-paced narrative.
The infectiously delightful exuberance of Frances that nearly vibrates off the screen is clearly tailor-made for the actress.
A restrained and well-tuned performance from Wasikowska; trademark levity from Driver that works to tremendous effect; beautiful scenery; stellar score; a richly rewarding final act.
An unexpectedly funny and entertaining story, an engaging main character to follow, explores a seemingly dry subject with pizzazz and pop.
Fidell still surprises with the direction of her film, and as honest as it is, as true as it feels, A Teacher still packs a punch.
Side Effects is a more than worthy film for anyone to end their career (well, maybe) on.

As an entry into the Iranian world, Schauder and Nodjoumi made a wise choice with sports, but they made an even better choice with Sheppard.
Quote not available.
On its own merits, Safe Haven is about as satisfying and filling as a Valentine's Day conversation heart, with far less to say.
It may not be an instant animated classic, but it's a charmer that will leave the kids ... feeling warm and fuzzy ...

Dupieux doesn't make films for everyone, but he does craft creative and abstract trips that are more than worth going on, even if they're fantastically difficult to explain to anyone who has yet to join the club.
Perry's film lags and limps along its two-hour runtime before finally going whole hog on one of the most dizzyingly weird final acts in recent cinematic history.
There are plenty more surprises in store for the couples who brunch and the lucky audiences who get to watch them do so.
Pain & Gain is one of the most truly crazy, ludicrous, self-reflexive, irony-free, bizarre, and entertaining films to get wide release in quite some time.
'Erased' is an entertaining enough action outing with plenty of well-done elements to recommend it.
It's fun to see Tatum and Foxx fire rocket launchers and make jokes about sneakers, but it's also compelling to care about their kids and their ladies and keeping all those people safe.
... a rapid-fire script and the inspired pairing of Bullock and McCarthy make 'The Heat' one of the funniest films of the year so far.
... a must-watch for fans of punk music, vinyl record wonks, or even those interested ... a visionary entertainment dream.
... it surpasses the hallmarks of its genre with an actually dramatic storyline and all-around solid acting. Just don't think you can go see it alone.
Labor Day is Reitman's most accomplished, mature, and emotional work yet.

An absolute technical marvel in every way possible -- from cinematography to special effects to sound design to score, all of Gravity's technical parts work together in perfect harmony for maximum effectiveness.
Even the most seemingly benign scenes posses a low level of fear, and the final hour is heavy enough to leave audiences shaking (and shaken).
[The final act is] a great half hour or so of film -- funny, charming, sad, satisfying -- but the rest of Philomena isn't so up to snuff.
Kabbalah Me is most satisfying as a personal artifact that traces Bram's quest, bumps and all, and it stumbles when it attempts to lay on educational aspects.

The music-heavy second half doesn't zip with much pizzazz, and even the film's many dips into song-and-dance fail to keep it moving along with anything resembling style. By its third act, things have flatlined.

Life Partners travels some very familiar ground, but the strength of its writing, the honesty of its plot, and the charm of its leading ladies means that it's a real cut above the rest of its genre brethren.
Gone Girl is a rare bird: a tricky, weird mystery that benefits from people knowing its twist from the outset.
The intimacy and immediacy of the situations and experiences it does portray are compelling and satisfying enough to stick with viewers for long after the film has ended.
Both Redmayne and Jones have been hovering on the cusp of breaking out in a big way, and The Theory of Everything is the ideal vehicle to capitalize on their talents and push them to the next level.
A satisfying and sweet debut film that will likely only get better with age (just like those eighties films).
Before I Go To Sleep vacillates so wildly between aims and issues that the conceit seems worthless.
Its connections run shallow, and most of its action-particularly in the over-the-top third act-feels spectacularly unearned.
All Relative fails to engage because the emotional connection between all parties is weak to nonexistent.
Cohen's insights into relationships are sharp, and Red Knot is an auspicious start for the filmmaker, one rife with good instincts, smart direction, and crisp writing.
The film skips around from time and place, a handful of transitions are smooth and natural while others don't fare nearly as well, and the effect is choppy and unrefined.
Love & Mercy may be built on its headlining talent, but Pohlad has also snagged a solid supporting cast to aid Dano and Cusack.
With's rapid and multiple changes of heart fly fast and furious in the film's first act, making it difficult to get a handle on either her motivations or her basic character.
Decker's sure hand and unique style keep Butter On The Latch swirling onward into weirder, woolier territory.
The depth of information present in Time Is Illmatic is one of its best aspects, and director One9 and screenwriter Erik Parker manage to blend the majority of it together quite seamlessly.
Romantically uninspiring and comedically unstable, And So It Goes is a poor excuse for a rom-com, even one that continually plays by the rules of the genre...
Combining some classic plot movements and plenty of modern trappings (just, like, a lot of cell phones), Earth to Echo is a sweet family film that has something for everyone.
An emotionally punishing experience.
Matthew McConaughey's quest to establish himself as one of the finest, most committed actors of his generation continues apace in Jean-Marc Vallee's fact-based Dallas Buyers Club.
Polley's ability to uncover truth and to present it for public consumption is bold and brave, and bodes well for her (hopefully) continued doc career.
As ever, le Carre subverts the spy genre in a major way.
Occasionally striking, often embarrassing.
Joe Swanberg's most mature and satisfying film yet.
A tightly constructed and cleverly designed take on the modern love story.
Aubrey Plaza is committed to the gag, but the rest of this messy and muddled zom-rom-com needed more guts.
An oddly fake and emotionally empty bromantic-comedy.
Vampire Academy ultimately doesn't have much bite, but that doesn't stop it from trying to continually show its teeth.
Mistaken for Strangers finds its footing in humor and good nature, and it's a thoroughly feel-good rock documentary with massive audience appeal, National fans or not.
Perhaps the most terrifying thing about The Quiet Ones is how blatantly the Hammer horror film rips off other, better features.

The film certainly feels both well-meaning and well-intentioned, but 42 can't quite find a suitable tone or flow, fluctuating between quiet moments that convey tremendous emotion and over-the-top, hammy, stagey, and exposition-heavy sequences.
Intramural is probably destined to become something of a cult classic, thanks to both its charming cast and a series of highly quotable lines.
An unsentimental but well-crafted look at San Francisco in 1985, during the early days of an epidemic that was just beginning to be understood.
This could hopefully be the start of a fun and worthwhile new franchise.
A rarity amongst recent releases, a film that really is both hilarious and heartfelt.
Sets the stage for better and fuller adventures to come.
"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is not his grandest work yet, but it is one worth an extended stay.
David Gordon Green is my favorite filmmaker of his generation, but The Sitter is one of the worst films of the year.

Hardcore Streep fans and bored history buffs will turn out, but the film is not likely to gain much traction from them.

Shame is a surprisingly universal story. It is not a film about sex addiction so much as it's a film about disconnection and obsession and need and consumption and seduction and trust -- human issues for a human story.
The stakes of Arbitrage never feel quite high enough, no matter how good it all looks.
Duplass and Plaza have lovely chemistry that's quite nice to watch unfold and they put in a pair of great performances
When the film allows itself to slack, it slumps almost irrevocably, and it never quite recovers from an unsatisfying and overemotional middle.
Despite a strong comedic cast, the film isn't particularly funny. Save the Date is a typical Sundance romance that doesn't ever set itself apart from its brethren.

It's remarkably well-crafted, as it looks good and sounds good and features a tight, economical script.
Toxic, nasty, and ugly.
Wrong will be a hysterical joy in the right hands.

The animation itself is beautiful and delightfully detailed, and the 3D is of the rare breed that makes the supposed "gimmick" look to have real value, the bow on top of the already lovely present that is Arthur Christmas.
For a film that revolves around the needs of and desires of creatures who are slaves to their hunger for the red stuff, Breaking Dawn is bloodless.

Though Haywire is very much the sort of slick, sassy Soderbergh we've come to expect from the prolific director, it's bogged down with a poor sense of story development and some less-than-clever plotting conceits.
If there's one lesson the film attempts to convey, it's that there is always sweetness left in the world, no matter what, and this is a big piece of it.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Boys working out their issues with their fists and feet isn't a particularly original metaphor, but Warrior makes some unexpected choices that allow the film to punch above its weight.
Is it still wrenching to watch? Yes, sweet goodness, yes.
Though the film benefits from an easy chemistry between the leads, it never hits any of the highs hinted at early on, leaving audiences unfulfilled by the possibility of what might have been.
Moneyball is a film about losers, but when those losers do manage to pull out a win, it's truly something to cheer.
Too silly to be confusing and too flaccid to reach potboiler status, the convoluted spy-thriller The Double is a tossed-off theatrical release that lands with a resounding thud.

A disquieting outing with little in the way of honest payoff.

Cody's snappy, spot-on writing and Reitman's clear-eyed direction should suit audiences looking for a black-as-night dramedy with bite.
A thoroughly enjoyable and engaging film.
An enormously entertaining and relatable family farce.
Hello I Must Be Going overcomes its formulaic plot with solid performances, genuine warmth and humor, and some uncloying honesty about the nature of relationships.
It's a truly informative documentary, though it sags on occasion, and feels much longer than its 110-minute runtime.

Your parents probably don't want to go to The Avengers this weekend (and that's okay!) but audiences can do far worse for themselves than to take a quick cinematic trip to John Madden's The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.

movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A dark and gritty take on the classic, Sanders succeeds mightily in the look and feel of his film, but his ability to direct his impressive cast is severely lacking.
Revolting, moronic, despicable, deeply unfunny, wildly offensive, and frankly disturbing.

It's a bouncy trifle that allows Allen to explore some of his favorite topics in a more light-hearted fashion, but while it cooks up a number of laughs and more than a few great performances, it's nothing less than a minor effort.
Seeking a Friend will benefit from great word of mouth and could last in theaters long enough to go out with a bang, not a whimper.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Brave is at its best when it's smartly and charmingly changing what we think think a Disney Princess can be, but it wavers when it tries to somehow reinvent the Pixar wheel.

When Red Flag really hits its stride, which happens somewhat late in its second act, it becomes the film it should be through and through -- a funny, well-observed, keenly acted feature about drama, trauma, and second chances.
It's not nearly as snappy or campy as it should be-though its self-seriousness is its own kind of entertainment.
Rashida Jones turns in a beautiful, multi-faceted performance that (if anything in Hollywood is fair) should push her into a higher level of roles and films.
Take This Waltz is an uncompromisingly human film -- especially when it delves into some of the deepest and most selfish of human desires -- and its swirl of emotion is hard to turn away from.
Slicked-up and dumbed-down
Frequently funny and layered with humor to suit all ages.
What works about Lawless may get audiences buzzed, but they'll never feel thrillingly soused.
It never feels like more than a second-tier video game brought to life.
The Lucky One is so dismal, so off-kilter, so nonsensical that even the ever-ready charms of Zac Efron cannot redeem it in the slightest.
Illuminating, oddly hilarious, ceaselessly watchable.

Safe House  isn't the most original of plots-it feels like a loose amalgamation of ten other spy flicks-but director Espinosa infuses his production with some bold choices, both in terms of technics and twists.
An impressively dark and well-crafted crime tale about, of all things, cattle farming and "the hormone mafia underworld."
Silent House's change-up from home invasion scarefest to limp psychological terror is bad, but worse yet, it's boring.

An intelligent spin on the found footage trope with solid scares in the second half and a great performance from Ethan Hawke.
The film focuses on the extreme limits of human fallibility and a true story that is so exceedingly unbelievable that it feels like it cannot possibly be true -- but it is.
It does not prove to be an ultimately rewarding experience.

Any true emotions are snuffed out by over-the-top shock humor that, though constantly ratcheted up, is only done so to conceal the film's tonal inconsistencies and unease when it comes to big questions.
Unfortunately, the film lacks any sort of suitable or satisfying entry point for the uninitiated, and might still prove to be a bit obtuse even for those who know what they're getting into.
Crazy Eyes feels a bit like a more light-hearted Leaving Las Vegas or a more energetic Somewhere -- comparisons that are meant as compliments.
While Somebody Up There Likes Me tracks decades in Max's life and innumerable changes, there's little actual evolution to be found.
A YA adaptation elevated by a talented cast, skilled direction, and a tone and story that feel vibrant and applicable beyond just this single film.

Technically speaking, the film is breathtaking -- made up of crisp and clear long shots, intimate peeks inside the rainforest, and a wealth of consistently used time-lapse footage that is jaw-dropping.
This thing flies, and even if its audience is reduced to looking up and pointing skyward, that's a pleasure in itself.
Berg's film is but a piece of the entire story, but it's an essential entry into the horrifying true life tale.
Make no mistake, Nightcrawler is a major work for everyone involved.
Olin is so spell-binding...just watching her is treat enough.

That a film about The Muppets would refer so often to Henson's work is a bit of a no brainer, but it also represents a larger point of Muppet Guys Talking, which is creativity is impossible without communication and collaboration.
movie_title: Muppet Guys Talking: Secrets Behind the Show the Whole World Watched (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A wicked spin on the often played-out world of indie romantic comedies, The Relationtrip packs every conceivable genre trope into a neat 90 minutes, and then happily upends them.

Tom Flynn's script isn't afraid of asking tough questions when it comes to Mary's fate... but couches the rest of the film in such superfluous material that it's nearly impossible to cut through the noise. In short, the math doesn't add up.
For a film that's built on such a banger of a premise, Mine never leaves Mike alone for too long, robbing it of the tension and terror that made Mike's early solitary moments hit so hard.
Pairing up talented comedians like Hawn and Schumer with a wacky plotline to match should spell comedy gold, but Snatched is about as cheap and disposable as a tourist trap tchotchke.
When Worthington and his wacky trio are allowed to loosen up, The Shack radiates with undeniable sweetness, but the darker elements grind it to an unnerving halt.
[An] amiable feature that boasts the kind of old-school charm and chemistry that more comedies could stand to tap into.
Bruce, you're better than this.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although All Eyez on Me occasionally dips into Tupac's complex nature, it always zips away the moment deeper motivations and themes are explored.
The whiz-bang joy of the first film is wholly absent, and "Despicable Me 3" limps along for nearly an hour before finding its footing (and, also, maybe an actual unicorn).
Tiffany Haddish is the best thing going in a film that has plenty else to recommend it, especially for audiences eager to see a truly wild summer comedy.

Collins' performance is certainly the main attraction here, but Noxon has rounded out the rest of her cast with equally as impressive supporting turns from performers as diverse as Reeves, Retta, Alex Sharp, Preston, and Lili Taylor.
The film is at its best when Dieckmann slows down the action and revelations for its real charm: two ladies, on the road, talking.
Jenkins' feature flips back through time to deliver an origin story that functions beautifully on its own while also bolstering excitement for the franchise's future.
The overall effect is one of a disjointed love story that can never quite find the tune, no matter how skilled its players.

From stories about children's choirs gone wild, unexpected romances and even a gut-churning immigration story that couldn't be more prescient, this year's live-action nominees fit together into a satisfying, smart little package.
Despite its looser tone, Darker does make room for some clunkier, darker elements.
No Stranger Than Love goes for weirdness way too late.
Gans isn't especially concerned with the outcome this coupling, instead reveling in overwrought and often bloated storytelling, lush details and some of the year's most unnerving CGI.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bÃªte) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I Saw the Light doesn't just fail to illuminate Williams' complicated life and his prodigious talent; it can't even capture the dark corners of a man with more than enough to peer into.
The film's ultimate reveal is hardly shocking, and that the film spends a gratuitous amount time unspooling it long after it's clear what has gone down feels indulgent and unearned.
This version... bogged down as it is by insipid narration and a punishing running length, makes this Voyage of Time a trip not worth taking.
"What is Morgan?" the film's marketing campaign has been asking for weeks. Turns out, Morgan is just another sci-fi film that's only engineered to disappoint.

Eventually, the missing pieces -- and the Amanda Knox case is undoubtedly one of missing pieces -- outshine the compelling elements the doc does provide (again, Amanda Knox! as primary talking head!), leaving audiences only wanting more.
Princess" is an arresting and taxing film experience.
Shining testament to the power of belief.
Unspools into nearly two hours of baffling narrative choices, weak character development, and so many offensive cliches that it would be funny if they wasn't so, well, offensive.
Too phony to love.
Marjorie Prime feels less true at every turn.
Shortland serves up something that's got plenty of bite to it, and Palmer gladly tears into it
Sevigny is the surprisingly subtle beating heart of the whole affair, while Parker appears to be having a hell of a time being a classic Perry villain.
Williams along with her burgeoning star power and ability to bring absolute charm and sparkle to every second of the film elevates it.

King's Dark Tower universe is rich with cultural reference points and is always totally unpredictable, but in cutting it down to consolidate its highlights, The Dark Tower can't even shoot the most necessary bullets straight.
"Columbus" is a feast for the eyes, but its more lasting impression is on the heart.
The Nut Job 2 goes full throttle on the timely stuff, resulting in a (slightly) more thoughtful and entertaining outing.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film that's been repeatedly edited into a bizarre, boring final product that packs as much punch as a light sneeze or a gentle cough. A fever it is not.
Nancy is a liar, but the trick is, we can't help but believe her. We want to.
Despite the built-in engine of The Long Dumb Road - literally; this is a road trip movie, after all - the film's second half struggles to find anything resembling direction.
At least it looks good.

It's the insights into [Ginsburg's] personal life that feel the most vital, moving "RBG" beyond the kind of information you could read on a Wikipedia page (as ably and entertainingly rendered as they may be on the big screen).

The stakes in "Beirut" are high (a high-ranking official has been kidnapped, and everyone seems convinced that he's going to spill all kinds of secrets), but [Jon] Hamm lopes through the process without much conviction.
Moverman's script, based on the Argentinian film Rompecabezas by Natalia Smirnoff, is graceful with the details and its characters.
Search doesn't require any further narrative tricks to prove Chagnaty's ability to use seemingly huge constraints to weave a unique film, one that maintains a near-perfect connect with its audience.

Production design from Stephanie Hamilton is another highlight, and the film feels pulled directly out of a very specific time and place; Jeremy Rouse's cinematography is gorgeous without being at all showy.
By the time the film chugs to its nonsensical ending, it's become a very familiar feeling indeed.

The love story at the heart of "Every Day" is a deep one, an inventive allegory that packs a timely wallop, but it's one hopelessly hampered by its resistance to engaging in the deeper issues it stirs up.
The only thing scarier than "Prey at Night" is the possibility that we might have to wait another decade for more of its very special mask-faced chills.
Gringo sags and slips in its middle, falling so flat that even its fast-paced and neatly tied up final 20 minutes can't get the energy back up.
As the film slowly builds its momentum into its jam-packed second act before winding down into a languorous finale, its biggest questions still linger. There are no answers, but art helps.
Unfortunately, too much of the biggest revelations feel like palmed-off traumas that dilute the real terror of the film, which should be easy enough to focus on.
Lord and Miller's sensibilities are continually clever, and The Lego Movie works hard to gradually deliver surprising payoffs to what seem to be throwaway bits.
"Eighth Grade" isn't a documentary, but it hews as close to the modern coming-of-age experience as currently seems possible.
Love & Friendship may not be traditional Austen, but it's pretty stellar Stillman.
The power and majesty of White Fang, a truly wonderful protagonist ... makes a journey worth taking.

"Bad Moms" may have leaned pretty hard on its R-rated material, but "A Bad Moms Christmas" uses it as a crutch, piling on expletives and out-there situations without considering the toll they take on the film's emotion.
Life is messy, but the sprawl that overtakes "Home Again" is unwieldy and unwise, and detracts from Witherspoon's predictably plucky performance.
Away from the beach and away from the raw honesty it forces out of its stars, On Chesil Beach heads towards shallow, cold waters.
It's hard to ignore the power of a story that can package unorthodox concepts in such readymade trappings.

It's a film about heroes and what we require from them, and why that often leads to wounds that may never heal. For Gyllenhaal, that amounts to a riveting and raw performance that never hits a false note.
... the film revels in playing up hinky parallels that rarely coalesce into anything of much substance. It sinks.
For all of its paint-by-numbers plotting, "Kodachrome" offers a few nifty twists...
For a film that chronicles the rise of a creator obsessed with reanimating the dead, "Mary Shelley" is utterly lifeless.
[jason] Clarke does wonders with the material, adding new dimensions and layers between what hit the screen and what lingered just out of frame.
"Jane" isn't just required viewing for fans of Goodall or animal lovers, but anyone seeking a classic in the making.
It's fun, but it's blockbuster overkill after an already-crowded summer season.

[Lana] Wilson is much more content to let Nemoto and his experience speak for itself, and the result is a rich, rewarding documentary that digs deep into major questions without being afraid of the answers.
Buirski's weaving together of material is most impactful in these mid-feature scenes, unspooling a rich and horrifying world that goes far beyond just Taylor's experiences.
Pettyjohn's charming performance is the sort of infectious breakout role that makes a film like Girl Flu really get into your system.
Happy Death Day may actually be too beholden to its forebears, if only because this horror film is at its very best when it's being funny.
Zhao's film derives its power from the truth that both drives it and inspires it, and the final result is a wholly unique slice-of-life drama.
Paddington 2 ticks right along through its initially dense plot, eventually settling on a compelling narrative.
It's a true winner and a genuine crowdpleaser, a human story told well through one incredible animal.
Most damning, however, is that the film no longer feels as if it belongs to Ophelia, but instead uses her for a different take on a well-known tale.
The result is a rich, stirring look at one of modern society's most enduring -- and yes, inspirational -- marriages, underpinned by political machinations that remain all too relevant.
Although the film is supposedly about movement, Growing Up And Other Lies frequently stalls out, and whole patches of it grind on without momentum or purpose.
Despite their characters' inability to function as adults, both Prediger and Weixler deploy enough charm to keep Olivia and Nicole engaging and interesting to watch.
Winstead can telegraph more with a head tilt or a flicker of her eyes than most of her generation can do with a wild hand toss and a mess of expositional dialogue.
The film aims to puts a compelling twist on the "most dangerous game" trope, but its few good ideas are overshadowed by baffling character decisions and grating plot twists.
Its message is repetitive without being enlightening, and the film and its participants insist on hitting the same beats without pause, until the concept loses all meaning.
"When I Live My Life Over Again" is a low-key pleasure with big rewards, the kind worth crooning about.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although the film appears to be aiming for pitch-black humor, it's all so mirthless that the result is genuinely ugly.
The golden age of the meet-cute rom-com fizzled out long ago, but the snappy, smart, and undeniably sweet "Man Up" fills that gap with ease, a new wave rom-com unafraid of old school trappings.
Elizabeth Banks, traditionally known for her comedic stylings, turns in an understated and intriguing turn as Detective Nancy Porter.
The film is a true two-hander-and Astin and Mulkey are mostly up for the task-but inept storytelling sinks the picture faster than anyone can bail it out.
Seeds Of Time neatly utilizes stunning nature photography, zippy animation, map-centric graphics, and stock footage to further clarify its subject matter.

A cautionary tale about the necessity of disclosures when purchasing an older home, Gil Kenan's "Poltergeist" borrows liberally from the classic film to revisit the story of a family, a house, and the portal that upends their lives, with limited results.
You already know what's going to happen, but at least you get to watch Johnson do it.
"Entourage"merrily skips over whole chunks of vital narrative in order to give it a glossy Hollywood ending, the kind that would seem forced, well, even in the movies.
Branaman's script piles on low-level drama, bad decisions, and enough misdirection to make the film's baffling ending feel not just unearned, but entirely unbelievable.
Like Sunday, Like Rain is so out of tune that even late-breaking attempts at emotion can't strike a chord.
The stakes of All The Wilderness aren't high, because Johnson never directs his attentions to the real issue at hand.
Keith is one of Grant's worst roles to date, and even his sparkling personality wears thin by the film's halfway mark.
Wild doesn't aim for high inspiration or fussy performances, and it benefits from staying honest and rich, instead of going for big speeches and bigger set pieces.
Wickedly entertaining.
It's bold, but it's not a film that's just trying to be bold; it's just trying to be real -- and it is.
Frank's film is much more of a noir outing than a straight action feature, and Neeson slips right into the tone and feel of the hard-boiled detective offering.

At turns charming and subtly complex, Le Week-End is no grand affair to remember, but it's a fine enough showcase for two winning talents and the sort of mature take on romance we don't see nearly often enough.

The film has enough charm and humor to keep it appealing to a wide audience, and dumbing things down doesn't feel particularly smart or canny, and proves to be a minor distraction to an otherwise majorly entertaining feature.
Desiree Akhavan cleverly skewers so much of what makes Brooklyn-set indies the subject of derision, but she does it with grace and humor, not with potshots or exaggerated gags.
Black Sea loosely rejiggers history to allow for a fantastic-sounding story-and treasure-to be pursued in a tightly wound twist on the common heist film.
Son Of A Gun, twists together a surprisingly original heist story with a more commonplace meditation on the ugliness (and the sometimes inevitability) of revenge.
The good-hearted and intermittently sweet Love, Rosie attempts through sheer force of will to convince viewers that its good-looking protagonists are a good match.
Although there are a handful of missteps, "Sleeping With Other People" is ultimately a satisfying charmer with a big payoff.

Although it's not essential for a filmmaker to insert their own experiences and opinions into a documentary that chronicles the lives of other people, Crystal Moselle's "The Wolfpack" proves to be a confounding exception.

Early interest in exploring low-grade delinquency, the kind of wacky wish fulfillment only a kid could pull off, are the film's high points, and it's too bad Watts couldn't keep careening down that path, lights cheerfully flashing, sirens giddily blaring.
The story of Leith may not be over yet, but viewers will clamor for some kind of resolution, if only to help them sleep at night.
"Prophet's Prey" is a skin-crawling chronicle of one of America's biggest criminals and the community that allowed him to flourish.
Vikander is the main event here, and if Testament Of Youth is a testament to anything, it's to her ability to embody great women with grace and battle-ready precision.
Mitta struggles to marry the film's melodramatic storytelling with its appreciation for dark and dreary history.
For all its half-cocked plotlines, "Ashby" is able to maintain a consistently humorous and light tone.
Cumberbatch is the main event here, making something almost impossible (capturing such a man as Turing in a tidy two-hour package) look easy, important, and appropriately imperfect.
At nearly 105 minutes, "Microbe and Gasoline" runs out of steam in its second act, but the majority of this sweet, sensitive ride is a real treat.
Despite a hefty number of tears shed throughout the course of the film, Kopple never plays up fraught situations for cheap emotions or knee-jerk reactions.
A female-driven story that doesn't shy away from bad behavior while also touting the importance of familial bonds and solid parenting choices.

It's not just that the people who populate "Masterminds" are at the mercy of their own bad decisions and worse judgement, it's that they're trapped in a woefully unfunny movie that seems to actively despise them.
Dunn plays around with perspective and style, but all the flash doesn't obscure the film's emotion and heart, which are deep and true.
Ouija giddily zips between haunted house thriller, exorcism drama and skillful period piece, all wrapped up in a neat and terrifying little bow.
Angelou herself is the star, one who is more riveting and original sitting in a chair, reciting the story of her life, than this -- or most, really -- documentary could ever hope to be on its own.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: War is hell, but "Allied" isn't much better, as it wastes a good idea and a better cast.
Captain America: The Winter Soldier neatly and entertainingly puts into motion some big changes in the Marvel universe, while still sticking to its own charms - no easy feat, but one fit for a hero.
Forbes' film is unencumbered by the clichÃ©s so often represented in other films about mental illness, and although Forbes' grasp on tone frequently wobbles, it never falls over.
One More Time is a low-key pleasure with big rewards, the kind worth crooning about.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's more than enough story to tell here, maybe too much for just one film, no matter how well-meaning it may be.
A soaring, sweet documentary that welcomes its audience into an unexpected new arena.
That's where the film truly succeeds: Frears doesn't treat Florence like a joke, and neither does Streep.

Although Seo and Ahn are able to tap into David's confusion and agony -- especially when filtered through the lens of his damningly hopeful parents -- there's never much more to David (or his story) than that.
Men Go to Battle... possess an admirable homespun appeal that is punctuated by an outstanding attention to detailâ.
Although "Tracktown" lacks edge, it's just so relentlessly sweet and Pappas is so effervescent on screen that those missteps in tone are easy to forgive.
"Titanic" in space? No, but it's certainly a disaster.

The charm of "The Meddler" isn't the kind that benefits from big pushes forward in narrative or massive plot movements, but it revels in heart-warming humor, vibrant characters and what's clearly a deep affection for its story.
The film makes its mark when it leans in on the deeply personal connection between its subject and its storyteller.
While he shines in his supporting role as the satisfyingly complex king, it's hard not to imagine what the film would have looked like with Rickman as the romantic lead.
"Even the best dance routines can't entirely raise the film from its shambling, directionless feeling, "
The story is rooted in real world concerns and practical issues.
Bahrani's dismantling of the American dream -- a dream deferred -- has finally reached its finest conclusion with the director's finely wrought (and seriously fraught) 99 Homes.
It's biopic syndrome... and it sinks the second half of an otherwise compelling, funny and extremely entertaining film with a beat all its own.
Clocking in at a slim 85 minutes, the whole thing flies by quite pleasingly, a warm and funny feature that reasserts the value of high quality visuals and attention to detail.
War is cruelty and it's Hell and it's terrible and it often feels eternal, but it breeds great heroes and wild stories, just like the ones within The Keeping Room, the kind you want to fight for.
Despite being rife with crime, sex and darkness, Manhattan Night feels increasingly like a cheap ripoff of the genre it so very much wants to fit into.
Although no one comes off looking especially good, an acceptable alternate title for the film could be "The Ugly Americans."

The film is tasked with cramming an entire life into the minimum of time, and it often comes up short when it comes to canny explorations and richer examinations of both Joplin's individual life and her greater legacy.

Laurent has an excellent eye for shot composition, and cinematographer Arnaud Potier's crisp photography aids the director in creating an enviable set of gorgeous and memorable shots, and the film is consistently visually compelling.

Romanowksy has gamely hacked through Elliott's purposely messy and tangential material to craft a workable portrait of pain and addiction, one that's bizarrely entertaining even in its most brutal moments, good enough for at least one hit.
"Tumbledown" strikes a delicate, moving tone that hits more high notes than lows.
In a landscape where superhero roles are too often seen as paycheck parts, Reynolds breaks the mold. Too bad his film doesn't.
Trachtenberg ratchets up the tension with ease, and even small things are filled with a stomach-turning dread that keeps the film chugging along until its explosive last act.
An edgy, ambitious nail-biter that keeps you poised to slip off the couch the whole way through.

As a movie, Fifty Shades Freed is charmingly stupid. As a cultural artifact, it's an escapist commercial for how being rich is awesome that is both totally out of step with the national mood and a cheeky, possibly accidental comment on it.

The flamboyantly peculiar erotics Shape of Water have not stopped critics and audiences from applauding it as a masterpiece. I applaud it for a different reason: for its ability to make a freaky fable about interspecies sex go mainstream.
As long as you don't walk in expecting to see Citizen Kane, I'm not sure how you could be disappointed.
Should be like a 'Shirley Valentine' sequel, but falls a little flat.
No doubt intended to be a Christmas blockbuster - this pretty looking film is ultimately all wrapping, with nothing much to find inside.
Refreshing and challenging.
As funny, silly and lovingly teasing as anyone could have hoped.
This is true-to-life teenage stuff.
Explores the line where caring becomes selfish rather than selfless.
Might have made a good episode of 'Entourage'.
Joyously ridiculous.
Tense right to the end.
The kind of horror movie you probably watched at a sleepover as a teenager.
The film's strengths lie in its sense of authenticity.
Unexpected and brilliant.
The kind of party you'll almost definitely never get an invite to.
Feels like you're watching an entire season of Modern Family in fast-forward
This adaptation of Jojo Moyes's best-seller (scripted by the novelist herself) might have the structure of a comfort-food weepie, but it's a rom-com with brains.

Vulgar and tasteless as usual, but most definitely longer and, quite obviously, to its detriment, uncut.

An affectionate rendering of adolescence in all its questionable glory.

Willful suspension of disbelief won't do it.

How strange to make a film about such a person yet turn them into an absence at the heart of it, in favour of a narrative that accentuates their powerlessness.

When Inge elopes with a soldier, Dinesen searches across the unforgiving but beautifully shot landscape, in a sort of western that turns into a surreal exploration of his existential angst, then segues to his descendants in the present day.

movie_review_blurb: Will she bring in the botanical build on time and on budget? Will the head gardener give her the green thumbs up? Or will it end in a vale of mud and tears for our horticultural hotties?

In luscious blacks and whites, this film noir thriller takes place in Little Italy, New York, and is a precursor to the cinema of Scorsese, with a touch of Hitchcock in its affectionate embrace of man's dark side.
There is much to recommend in Woman in Gold.
Rurouni Kenshin 3: The Legend Ends -- and that's a relief.
movie_title: Rurouni Kenshin: The Legend Ends (RurÃ´ni Kenshin: Densetsu no saigo-hen) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [Gosling] seems to have dug up some lurid offcuts from a Nicolas Winding Refn movie, and mashed then up with David Lynch and Edward Hopper.
Russell Crowe's first effort as a director provides four movies for the price of one.

"Blade Runner is a film set 40 years hence, made in the style of 40 years ago," Ridley Scott said of his celebrated science-fiction noir. Perhaps that other-worldly "retrofitted" look is why it seems ageless, despite being set in 2019.
The Duff is your typical high-school misfit comedy, elevated by a kooky, cranky and deeply sympathetic performance by Mae Whitman.
While there are some powerful emotional moments, the sense of despair is enervating.
"Cars don't fly!" is the recurring cry in Fast and Furious 7 and in scene after improbably hilarious heavy-metal crashing scene, this idea is disproved.
The film-making is clunky, the voiceover from dealer Sirus (Nathanael Wiseman) is irksome and the gangster-police showdown is merely a showcase for some severed fingers and very large guns.
Darlings, just breathless with the news: Kenneth Branagh's Cinderella is a sumptuous, candy-coloured rush of romance, with added thespian backbone from Cate Blanchett as the evil stepmother.
Robot Overlords would be better as a children's television series than a cinema release, despite the presence of Ben Kingsley and Gillian Anderson.
Blind takes a fresh look at reality and fiction, through the unseeing eyes of Ingrid (an uncanny performance by Ellen Dorrit Petersen).
The film is shouldered by a powerful performance by Game of Thrones star Nikolaj Coster-Waldau.
Rarely have layers of truth been so expertly peeled away than in About Elly, a drama from the Oscar-winning director of A Separation.
The Salvation is of that rare genre: the Danish western, starring the always-magnificent Mads Mikkelsen as Jon, a Nordic settler in the (extremely) Wild West of America in 1871.

Atmospheric, insightful and darkly funny.
A gripping and stylish French thriller set among mafia mobsters in Marseilles.
He is is infinitely watchable, but Al Pacino's decision to star in the schmaltzfest of Danny Collins was a mistake.

Heartbreaking [and] deeply sympathetic.

[An] unfortunate mix of documentary footage and reconstruction.
movie_title: The Man Who Saved the World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Olivier Assayas'] real genius is casting Kristen Stewart as Binoche's harried and bespectacled personal assistant, Valentine.
A Royal Night Out is a right royal mess, despite Buckingham Palace being staffed by some fine actors.
In all, a terrific experience.
Avengers: Age of Ultron delivers the usual superhero suspects in a slick, if overlong, adventure that bungee jumps between banter and action.
The action includes an amusing scene featuring a chest freezer and a helicopter.
Straightforward and solid.
Phoenix is full of ambiguity and intelligence.
Spooks addicts will probably be satisfied, but those used to the ambition and mega-budgets of Bourne and Bond may feel shortchanged.

Samba is blessed with the large presence of Omar Sy.
Tilda Swinton's performance as Orlando in this adaptation of Virginia Woolf's novel is luminous and thrilling, an omnisexual romp through 400 years of history.
If you like your zombie movies ultra-violent, ironic and delivered in a power-shower of blood, then Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead will be right up your street.
As outrageous as it is insightful, Mommy is a mother-and-son melodrama taken to operatic heights.
I found it unbearably boring and mannered.

Quality oozes from every pore, with John Schlesinger's direction complemented by Frederic Raphael's sharp script and a cast that includes Julie Christie, Alan Bates, Peter Finch and a dastardly Terence Stamp.
A 1980s New York organised crime thriller that confounds the mobster mould.
It turns out that the sharp-tongued humour of Groucho Marx is ageless, the slapstick timely and the subject matter still pertinent: loony dictatorship, religion, pointless warfare.

A movie that appears to be about wrestling but in fact is a disturbing, testosterone-rich tour of the inadequacies of an American billionaire and his athletic protÃ©gÃ©.
Looking at La Maison de la Radio in the wake of the Charlie Hebdo crisis, what strikes you is how conventional and white French state radio seems.
While this was all no doubt galling for Schrader and Kosuth, you don't get the sense that there is a masterpiece lurking somewhere underneath.
Despite its title, The Theory of Everything is less about astrophysics and more about the quantum mechanics of human relationships under pressure.
With limited resources [Jeremy Lovering] has created a disturbingly tense and chilling scenario we can all identify with.
Enjoyable horror-lite.
Blue Ruin starts promisingly with a hairy hobo living in a blue, rusty, bullet-holed Pontiac on a Delaware beach.
Cinema has always been the best place for time travel, but rarely has it been so anchored in reality than in Richard Linklater's Boyhood.
Imagine for a moment that Marilyn Monroe - in a black wig and outfitted in tarty Primark - is dropped into the dreich streets of Glasgow, and drives round in a white van picking up eager young men.
Sometimes a film leaves you with a big, dumb grin on your face. The Marvel blockbuster Captain America: The Winter Soldier... is such an item.
In proper "who gives a toss?" B-movie tradition, Guardians of the Galaxy takes us into the silly section of the Marvel Universe.
[Lake Bell] steals the show with her rubbery, expressive face, penchant for self-humiliation and believable English accent.
Funnily enough, the producers of the Twilight series are behind the latest teen adaptation, but The Fault in Our Stars is a more serious take.
Bar. Big breasts. Bodyguard. Jason Statham! Cockney, mate. Vegas, innit?
The film deep-mines those American high-school tropes, from bullying at the lockers and cold-shouldering in the cafeteria to panicking about the prom, and, of course, sexual awakening.

When Hollywood adapts great literature into a movie, it is best not to expect too much, and merely feel thankful that anything has been salvaged. But the treatment that has befallen Suite FranÃ§aise seems particularly harsh.
As subversive as it is hilarious.
The film focuses on the moving and complex relationship between Hirut (Tizita Hagere) and her lawyer Meaza Ashenafi (Meron Getnet) as they battle a death sentence and prejudice against women.
While Moore has deserved an Academy Award for years... the surprise is Stewart, who has left the twilight zone and burst forth as a creature of brutal honesty on screen.

Director Kim Longinotto somehow inveigles her camera into the lives of prostitutes, abused teenagers and drug addicts on the streets of Chicago, and elicits confessions and revelations that leave you gasping.
If only I could have left Unfinished Business unfinished... Five minutes would have been enough with this dull, dated tosh, so flaccid were the jokes.
The movie won five Oscars and, if anything, improves with age.
It's a work of hysterical excess and flamboyant extravagance and it feels unlike pretty much anything else you will ever see in a cinema.
White God is perhaps the greatest dog movie made without CGI.
Pelo Malo, which translates as "bad hair", takes a child's-eye view of growing up mixed race in the slums of Caracas, Venezuela.
[A] promising debut from the British directors Daniel and Matthew Wolfe.
One of the great MGM musicals.
From the opening scene of pale young men racing barefoot along the beach, full of hope and elation, backed by Vangelis's now famous anthem, the film is utterly compelling.
Sometimes cinema should just be pure, unadulterated joy, and The Artist is precisely that, in every wordless frame.
Think World of Interiors meets The Little Book of Bondage, and you may get the picture, which starts out hilarious, becomes ludicrous and finally dubious.

Jessica Hausner's Amour Fou frames German Romanticism from a female perspective, gently poking fun at the true story of the selfish, pompous poet Heinrich von Kleist and his suicide pact with Henriette Vogel in 1811.
I was intrigued by the prospect of the always-compelling Eddie Marsan playing a dull south London council funeral administrator in Still Life.
In Selma, British actor David Oyelowo subtly transmogrifies himself into Martin Luther King Jr, displaying intelligent self-doubt, not flash political pomp.

The Turning is a collection of nine short films based on Tim Winton's stories, some of which are more satisfying than others but in all they give a sense of Australian landscape and life at the edges.

Son of a Gun is an entertaining heist thriller starring Ewan McGregor that takes the well-trodden territory of the prison break and the criminal afterlife and sets it in the gold mines, beach resorts and skanky motels of Australia.
If The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel was the cinematic equivalent of a comforting chicken tikka masala ready meal, then its sequel has been left in the freezer too long and reheated to lukewarm.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: By 3am, as the film trickled to a halt, most of us wished we had stayed in our own beds.
This fourth outing for Daniel Craig as James Bond is achingly cool, as sleek and powerful as the silver Aston Martin DB10 that races through the movie.

This is not merely bravura stadium prog-rock for Pink Floyd fans, but a curious home road movie.
[An] insightful, often comic movie.
Pierce Brosnan's recent career is not a thing of beauty. Yet again he has plumped for a mildly embarrassing, past-its-sell-by-date part.
Michael Caine is the epitome of Sixties cool in his first outing as the secret agent Harry Palmer.
Life is a paean to the lost days when matinÃ©e idols were preserved in luminous black and white, in magazine spreads that allowed photojournalists to indulge in deep coverage for months.
It creeps slowly up on the viewer: a drip-feed of fear fed by creaks, eerie children and shadowy demonic figures on the periphery of this world and the next.
A tense, morally complex and extremely prescient thriller.

A hodgepodge of comic melodrama, more panto than pathos.
Hopkins is always good value, and the plot has plenty of gory twists.
A gripping Robinson Crusoe-style survival story.
Truman Capote's non-fiction masterwork gets the film noir treatment from director Richard Brooks, with a slow dissection of "a crime that shocked a nation."
Unfortunately the film supporting [Hardy's] performance, written and directed by Brian Helgeland, is disappointingly muddled, with a script that falls into banalities.
[Shyamalan] embraces the shaky-cam joys of found footage like a brand new toy. It's just, like, so last year.

After Meryl Streep sang her dungarees off in Mamma Mia!, I had great hopes for Ricki and the Flash.
Perhaps Waters' best known movie.
Dope is a high-school comedy written with wit, brio and the unexpected twist of a geeky hero who wants to go to Harvard, but finds himself in [a] drug-dealing snakepit.
Iranian director Jafar Panahi is under house arrest but, a testament to his ingenuity, Closed Curtain is the second in a trilogy of films shot clandestinely.
[A] woozy, erotic and disturbing Southern indie-gothic concoction.
It's a visual banquet of a film, which meditates on ageing with wit and tenderness.
The film remains mostly boxed up in the kitchen, and the upstairs-downstairs tension, in both senses, dissipates.

A compelling courtroom documentary.
We return to Eel Marsh House, that spooky, bog-bedeviled pile haunted by the woman who clearly does not think orange is the new black, and holds a bit of a grudge against children as a species.

movie_review_blurb: [A] charming, witty, politically lacerating drama.
Do I Sound Gay? humorously tackles the thus-far unaired and touchy question of whether certain intonations and speech patterns mark out some gay men the second they say hello.
The pursuit of happiness takes on a meandering, philosophical and richly visual form in Andrei Tarkovsky's Stalker.
A hyper-charismatic performance from Michael Fassbender combines with whip-cracking dialogue from Aaron Sorkin in Steve Jobs.

Soon it all gets bloody as the (somewhat unconvincing) lycanthrope goes loco on the locomotive.
Davies's film displays his usual lyrical sense of place in the rain-lashed rural landscape near Aberdeen, and brings a tranquil, almost Vermeer-like quality to the plain interiors of the farmhouse.

The explosions are subtler than you might expect, and Lebed is superb in the role.
Hotel Transylvania 2 is a consistently amusing vampire animation.
By the pricking of my thumbs, something crass this way comes. Avoid.
Who knew that a documentary on the Soviet Union's Red Army ice hockey team would be so gripping and provide a perfect microcosm of the stages of the Cold War, Perestroika and Putin's reign?
One of the great Ealing comedies of the 1950s.
An edgy, daring and often tasteless comedy.
The thrilling opening sequence of the drugs cartel movie Sicario is a humdinger -- and a stomach churner.
[He Named Me Malala] provides a delightful, profound and surprisingly funny insight into her life before, and later when she became a worldwide campaigner for girls' education.

In director [Suffragette], votes for women are not about the purple and green silk sashes and magnificent hats of the upper classes... but rather about a working class laundress with caustic soda on her hands -- and inequality eating into her soul.

The Walk is sometimes easier to watch with your eyes shut, just for a few seconds' respite from the plunging peril of being poised, wobbling, 110 storeys above the 3D void on a tightrope over Manhattan.
A baby-voiced, buxom, battling Barbara Windsor stars in all her glory in this warm-yer-cockles Cockney drama that borders on panto at times.
[Guillermo del Toro's] grandiose ambitions to update the haunted house story result in a lurid mess, entertaining for all the wrong reasons.
From the opening scarlet-and-black titles, Shakespeare's play is more eviscerated than adapted, in a lean, mean and powerful piece of cinema.
Ennui and anxiety... pervades Antonioni's groundbreaking 1962 drama.
Why do film-makers insist that Zac Efron must have regular shirtless epiphanies in the shower?
One of the few Marvel superheroes you'd happily take down the pub.
While the images chosen by the Japanese arthouse director Naomi Kawase are exquisite and arresting, the narrative is a dull, New Age meander.
Housebound does ghosts in the walls with the same wacky panache as the recent Wyrmwood did Aussie zombies.
[A] surreal and funny feast.
As ill-conceived as it is ill-spelt, Terminator Genisys fires a rocket-propelled grenade into its own franchise.
The big, brash laughs are coupled with a smart insight into women's friendships.
The Burning attempts to take the spaghetti western into the Argentine rainforest.
Accidental Love fields a top-level cast in a low-level comedy that combines the peculiar subjects of a nail in the brain, and pork-barrel Washington politics.
Holmes has been exhumed once again, in a long, slightly dull, tasteful British-Sunday-afternoon adaptation.
100 Bloody Acres is yet another cheap'n'cheerful Australian comedy-horror film, made with gusto by Colin and Cameron Cairnes.

Kemp tries to be butch, with his grey slicked-back hair and war-worn features, but somehow you expect him to pick up his bass guitar and break into True or Gold. The rest of the acting is exceptionally wooden.
Humongously enjoyable and gloriously predictable.
1971 is a fascinating documentary that unearths the human story behind a burglary of the FBI offices in Media, Pennsylvania, when every secret file was stolen.
An amusing portrayal of Jackie Fullerton.
What's fascinating is not merely the plot, but the wonderfully shot background, red and green neon on a grey townscape.
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In How to Marry a Millionaire, directed by John Negulesco, there is the triple delight of Marilyn Monroe, Betty Grable and Lauren Bacall in one movie -- and one apartment.
An action-comedy that takes the bankrupt Bond genre out for a fresh and subversive airing.
Queen and Country is John Boorman's autobiographical sequel to the wonderful Hope and Glory and a rather softer affair.

Those who are used to 2001: A Space Odyssey or A Clockwork Orange will initially find this black-and-white First World War drama starring Kirk Douglas rather traditional, until its radical content is revealed.
The leads are played with freshness and mischief by Lika Babluani as Eka and Mariam Bokeria as Natia.
The Look of Silence is a superbly crafted, earth-shattering documentary.
Addicted to Sheep is the rather racy title of a charming documentary about a year in the life of a family on a hill farm in the north Pennines.
P'tit Quinquin immerses you in the bucolic life of a French village near Boulogne, where a serial killer seems to be chopping up bodies.
In some glorious zone between Mad Men and Thunderbirds comes this X-Men prequel, as kinetic as it is character-driven, and full of ridiculous retro pleasures.
[A] devastating, glinting miniature of a drama.
There is something voyeuristic and manipulative about the handling of the material.
At first the film seems overly stagey, and those with little time for circus acts may find it irritating, but when Jodorowsky hits his surreal stride.
[Boasts] sly wit, charm and gorgeous black-and-white Scottish seascapes.
The Treatment brought me close to a panicked run for the cinema door on a number of occasions, but I held steady through this compelling and horrifying police search for a Belgian paedophile.

The movie contains a subtly crazed performance from Benicio del Toro as Escobar: one moment fooling around with his children in the hacienda swimming pool, fondling his gold taps, the next executing his enemies.
Pressure is certainly the most predictable and formulaic film of the week.
What a piece of petit bourgeois mediocrity it is.
The Man from U.N.C.L.E. delivers its spy action in a retro package, with lashings of irony.

If you liked the first Ted film, which launched Seth MacFarlane's potty-mouthed teddy, you may still find the second offensive, not because of its daft man-child humour, but its ill-judged attempt at comic racism.
Vittorio De Sica's Bicycle Thieves is tender and immediate, a simple tale of a man whose bike is stolenwhen his job and life depends upon it.
If you want to watch insanely dangerous stunts, done by a 53-year-old human and not a body double or a CGI pixel, then Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is the summer action film for you.
A glorious documentary fashionistas will want to study, frame by frame, while the rest of us are inspired by Apfel's zest for life and fondness for costume jewellery on an epic scale.
Cub is from that niche genre, Belgian cub scout horror-slasher movie, and would not win Baden-Powell's approval.

Tthe ordinary trauma of an 11-year-old girl coming to terms with a new life and school while losing all her old, comforting, childish certainties has become a glittering, bravura piece of cinema, a comedy both wise and tender.
Carlyle himself stars as a dangerously unhinged barber in a less-than-salubrious salon and Emma Thompson plays his equally terrifying mother in a fake leopard coat.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With a pleasurably peculiar cast of James Fox, Mick Jagger and Anita Pallenberg, Performance is one of the weirdest slices of Seventies London around, combining gangster violence and ritual humiliation with decaying rock-star glamour.
Best of Enemies tell the story behind the gripping and often howlingly funny Sixties television debates between two American intellectuals: William Buckley Jr. and Gore Vidal.
Inception is a grown-up thriller ride through the dreamscapes of the mind, with Leonardo DiCaprio in the lead. The movie is a sign that Hollywood retains some intellectual oomph.

When Marvel brought in Alan Taylor, the director of Game of Thrones, to invigorate the Thor franchise, many hoped for a breast-bearing, dwarf-battling, blood-spurting melodrama -- with capes and hammers. Sadly, it was not to be.
Ilo Ilo deals with that perennial dilemma of the middle-class working parent: how to deal with the live-in nanny who begins to usurp your role.
Quite possibly the greatest romantic comedy since Some Like It Hot.
Look into Janet Leigh's eye after the shower scene and be amazed how fresh this black-and-white ghoulish chic seems in the saccharine surroundings of modern cinema.
The wacky, amateurish derring-do of the six-man crew, led by the lanky, floppy haired PÃ¥l Sverre Valheim Hagen as the ethnographer Heyerdahl, is astounding.
This latest Star Trek wavers entertainingly between the silly and the Shakespearean. After a shaky, old-school start, the comedy comes at warp speed.
In the annals of superhero movies, this is not the most thrilling, but it does contain two Downton Abbey jokes, and a stonking performance from Downey.

Like Cianfrance's Blue Valentine, which also starred Gosling, this film deepens with a second viewing, the repeats, coincidences and echoes in scenes creating almost a genetic memory of a previous life.
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone makes the classic mistake of thinking a comedy about magicians will be magical.
The veteran director Ken Loach hoists the red flag with The Spirit of '45, a polemical documentary filled with hope and heroism, which takes a look at the resurrection of Britain after the war.
The Paperboy is flawed, more deserving of a rubbernecking than a viewing. But it's hard to tear your eyes away.
A film that takes a psychedelic ride into the blackest pits of the subconscious.
A strange hybrid, which dips into spurty horror and Lynchian parody, with added sexual awakening and shoe fetishism.
It's atmospherically photographed by Ben Smithard. But the plot is too thin for the big screen; it may have suited TV more.
And we're back! Slam bang in Middle-earth as though the Lord of the Rings trilogy never went away, which it didn't.
You cannot help but applaud Hooper for this brave attempt, which will probably please fans of Glee and Susan Boyle everywhere.

This is a date movie that caters to the needs of both men and women: American football and comedy, ballroom dancing and romance. Silver Linings Playbook covers all those bases -- and rises above them too.
One of the best documentaries out this year, and a must-see for Senate and Congress in America.
Heads roll, sparks fly, wolves howl and the cinema audience collapses, weak with laughter.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The notoriously "unfilmable" On the Road merely slides from hedonism into mild disillusionment.
Tim Burton is back on old-fashioned Stygian form with Frankenweenie. It's an animated children's film sufficiently dark and twisted to provide adult amusement too.
Skyfall is a resurrection, and will go down as one of 007's best.
Perhaps one in ten of the jokes hits the mark; the rest are damp, childish squibs
It's a perfect storm of bonkersness.

More an action blockbuster than a horror squelcher, it contains spectacular crowd scenes that have a Hieronymus Bosch quality, but the film lacks strong meat - of the emotional and bloody zombie-cannibal sort.
[An] eerie, sad, unflinching film.
The audience is held in a vise of claustrophobia, and every room seems full of tiny, screaming children.
This is seat-chewingly tense, virtuoso cinema that explores and exploits space as never before, with 3-D so convincing the audience lurches and gasps as though on a fairground ride.
Seve is for dedicated golf fans only, but there is some charm to this drama-documentary on the rise of Severiano Ballesteros from Spanish farmer's boy to world-class golfer.
I am delighted to say that in the cheerily crass Walking on Sunshine we have a strong contender for the worst British movie of 2014.
An assured and moving debut by director Diego Quemada-DÃ­ez.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Maxine Peake is a caricature of a childless, sharp-suited London career woman in Keeping Rosy.
Chef is a foodie-gasm of a film, directed by and starring Jon Favreau as a designer cook past his sell-by date, who goes on a road trip from Miami to Los Angeles to find his soul -- and soul food.
Bicycling with MoliÃ¨re is a droll, intellectual delight, and probably one for Francophiles who have at least a vague knowledge of MoliÃ¨re's play The Misanthrope.
McCarthy's latest vehicle, Tammy, misfires.

Full of subtle erotic tension, the 1948 drama focuses close up on Yuwen (Wei Wei), a frustrated, exquisitely beautiful housewife whose husband Liyan (Shi Yu) is invalided by tuberculosis and the traumatic effects of the Sino-Japanese war.
Not so much a turkey as a dodo, Grace of Monaco never takes flight and extinction is probably the best course for it.
In terms of Oscar promise, The Master is the one to watch for this year, with two unparalleled performances from Philip Seymour Hoffman and Joaquin Phoenix.
This clay animation feels as if it was written by the early Woody Allen. Actually the genius behind it is Adam Elliot, who wrote, designed and directed this eccentric, wryly funny story.
An Autumn Afternoon by the great Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu is as exquisite and delicate as his other works, but has the added poignancy of being his last film.
This new release is business as usual - more comic comfort blanket than novelty surprise.

The tale, which would be unwatchable in unexpurgated reality, is told instead with carved clay figurines, doll's house-sized stage sets and archive footage of Pol Pot's bloody and brutal takeover in 1975.
Call Me Kuchu leaves you flabbergasted by its portrait of the persecution of gay men and lesbians in Uganda.

Jawdropping and jawbreaking stunts performed by professional snowboarders open Lucy Walker's latest documentary, but it is the aftermath of accidents that form the powerfully disturbing core of the film.
The second instalment of The Hunger Games plays out in a bizarre zone where Simon Cowell meets Leni Riefenstahl.
With this powerful, almost classical drama, British director Steve McQueen has made the seminal film about slavery that Hollywood feared to tackle.
James McAvoy gives his best performance to date as a morally and physically decaying detective in this hallucinogenic adaptation of Irvine Welsh's novel.
Hirschbiegel shows no signs of a cinematic heart beating in his portrayal of the self-anointed "Queen of Hearts", and rarely goes beyond made-for-television territory.
The importance of Location, Location, Location in the British psyche cannot be overemphasised. Joanna Hogg's brilliantly austere and intimate portrait of a marriage recognises this.
There's much to love, and much to loathe about Joe Wright's new adaptation of Anna Karenina.
The most anticipated movie of the summer is as ambitious and bombastic as they get, with widescreen mayhem, thousands of extras, hyper-kinetic effects, and a roiling, twisting plot.
Yet another generation will bear the Spiderman emblem on their lunchboxes and pencilcases, and there's no harm in that. With great power comes great responsibility -- and an endless franchise.
Green Zone is probably the nearest the Americans will get to the public floggings of the Chilcot Inquiry except there will be popcorn on hand and a far larger audience.
Scorsese is capable of making a fascinating psychological thriller, but this effort is sub-Tarantino, without the irony.
Bettany's job: rescuing the modern Mary, a skanky waitress, and saving her unborn child. Our job: holding back the laughter.
With its ridiculous but rather charming plot and gorgeous Irish seascapes, the film also tries to tackle alcoholism and drug-dealing, with mixed results.
Burton treats his material with abandon, but not contempt, and he has brought his Mad Hatter's imagination to a new generation who have not yet read the books.
Travolta eventually becomes a parody of himself: with nudge-nudge references to the Royale cheeseburger, famously of Pulp Fiction.

Harrison Ford is the clichÃ (C) of a scientist who cares more for equations than humans, and works to atrocious rock music. The child actors are cloying in their cuteness. A serious subject drowned by sentimentality.
Hits the traditional horror buttons, while also showing some scary government genocide.
JeunetÃ¢(TM)s fondness for the whimsical and slapstick has gone over the top, leaving plot and character floundering.
The Bounty Hunter marks a new low and a new genre: the bail-bondage rom-com.

Under the hammy direction of Peter Jackson The Lovely Bones has lost its poetic bone structure. What was a complex, quirky novel has been turned into a movie mishmash of Lord of the Rings and High School Musical, with a serial killer thrown in.
The film is an aesthetic pleasure, like being in a designer hotel, reading a deliciously sad novel.
Bombarded by clichÃ©, you wilt in your seat like a discarded rose.
Invictus may be a rather cheesy way into the story of South Africa, but in the end you're glad it's there for a new generation to whom the words "Free Nelson Mandela" are history.

Julien Temple's rockumentary Oil City Confidential looks like a series of Martin Parr photographs of the British by the seaside, and then segues into thrashing guitars on the Seventies New York stage.
This is a sweet, comic drama, which seems to hail from another time.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Anonyma - Eine Frau in Berlin (A Woman in Berlin) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It seems ageless, despite being set in 2019. This is a future more murky than shining, where hardened men move among the lowlife in a warren of streets lit like an Edward Hopper painting, below pyramid-like skyscrapers.
This 3D remastering of the original, on a giant Imax screen to boot, brings a whole new sense of wonder to Dorothy's yellow-brick road movie.
Alfred Hitchcock's classic is as thrilling as it is witty, and contains at least two of cinema's great action set-pieces.
Kids will love it, and adults may relish Pierce Brosnan's Centaur, and Steve Coogan as Hades - in his personal hell just under Hollywood.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's pure joy as I Should Have Known Better, And I Love Her and Tell Me Why pour out over footage of thousands of screaming, weeping schoolgirls with bouffant hair and miniskirts pursuing John, Paul, George and Ringo.
The film has flaws, but its sheer exuberance deserves viewing.
With a bright explosion of politics, Kangol caps, Air Jordans, gold chains and Ralph Lauren Polo shirts, Fresh Dressed charts the genesis of hip-hop fashion in American culture.
In the end, the Prometheus plot is slightly bonkers, but forgivably so, because the characters are so well drawn. And there are enough slime bursts to make Ghostbusters look timid.
Rarely does a blockbuster live up to its overheated hype, but The Hunger Games proved to be an exception. Lawrence and this franchise will go far.

A cornucopia of cleavages and lingering close-ups of Robert Pattinson's trouser department. For some readers, that may be a strong recommendation. Others may find this version of Guy de Maupassant's 19th-century novel unintentionally hilarious.
By the end, the heavy-handed soundtrack turns Trishna into a musical about room service, as Frieda Pinto trots in and out with a tray and other offerings.

There's a delightfully unfashionable cheesiness about John Carter, a film for all the family, but in particular sci-fi fantasy geeks and older gentlemen who have never been able to relinquish the spiffing derring-do of Burroughs.
This latest Twilight is a freakish hybrid: part medical horror, part cheesy Victoria's Secret catalogue shoot.
Despite dazzling man-meets-machine design and similar themes, this film does not have the complexity of Avatar and for some it may feel rather like being trapped in a long video game.
Agora feels like an overlong school trip to the planetarium, followed by a Romans-in-togas play in the gym.
Allen has assembled a cast of incredible ability, but the result is hampered by his script.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Bullock turns in a terrific, ball-breaking performance. Unfortunately, the rest of the film is painfully patronising.
This is a work of stylish, existentialist brutality, filled with beautiful women and damaged men.
Beneath the information overload there are some great performances, and Douglas is still terrific, though increasingly raddled.
A gloriously tacky Italian romance.

Lurching between comedy and agony, Noah Baumbach's new film appears to be the simple tale of a man recovering from a nervous breakdown. Yet Greenberg resonates for days afterwards, like a hangover after a peculiar and fascinating party.
The depiction of the grieving producer's wife and children is agonising in its truth.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A cool, surreal film, and not a little fishy.

The film might have triumphed as a musical: camp, virtually plotless, and liberally sequined. But sadly this sequel is not Sex and the City -- it is Menopause in the Desert, and a waste of four great characters.
A worthy film that pales in comparison to Schindler's List, despite intelligent turns from Ulrich Tukur and Steve Buscemi.
Great gunslinging cinema creates icons, and the newest and tiniest of them all is Hit Girl.
A mash-up of the Master of Suspense and newsreel from the Cold War, playing on Hitchcock's obsession with doppelgÃ¤ngers.
Black Death is a nasty, brutish film that is far too long.
Return to Homs is a shocking, visceral documentary made among young Syrian fighters under siege from President Assad's snipers in the devastated city of Homs.
The simplistic Here and Now explores that teenage rite-of-passage perennial, where a cool, streetwise city kid is sent to the country and finds that the yokels are not quite as awful as expected.
Finding Vivian Maier is one of those fascinating documentaries that unearths an unknown artist and in a slow reveal creates a tantalising and ambiguous picture of the "missing" person.
Fans of the great populist film critic Roger Ebert will be both moved and amused by Life Itself.
Bowie's many incarnations from Ziggy Stardust to the Thin White Duke make appearances and it is oddly moving seeing his song lyrics written on lined A4 in cursive, schoolboyish hand.
The Case Against 8 is a documentary on the Californian repeal of same-sex marriage laws and has the tension of a legal thriller as well as being surprisingly moving in its final scenes.
One Rogue Reporter is an entertaining but jejune documentary that tackles tabloid journalism like an angry rottweiler.

Director Andy Goddard makes atmospheric use of black-and-white cinematography and 1950s settings, but aside from one scene of drunken confession by the fireside in a Connecticut cabin, the story fails to engage.
Jacques Tati's Playtime is an astringent antidote to Paris movies that are as sickly as macaroons and stuffed with views of the Eiffel Tower by night.
Leviathan has the heft of a proper, old-fashioned Russian novel.
Part of the sheer joy of this movie -- aside from the comic timing of Bill Murray -- is the cartoonish crapness of its apparitions and their placid acceptance by the Ghostbusters team.

The weird filmography of Shia LaBeouf, from Fury to Nymphomaniac via Transformers, continues with an ecstasy-fuelled excursion to eastern Europe in the bizarre The Necessary Death of Charlie Countryman.

The blow-by-blow dramatisation of the disastrous attempt in 2006 to rescue injured servicemen... shows the soldiers of 3 Para at their selfless best, but high command and communications at their worst.

If there is one film you should see on the largest screen possible this year, it is Mr Turner, which is not merely the portrait of an artist but a full-frontal, joyous bellyflop into the seascapes of his paintings.
Gyllenhaal, in a disturbing humdinger of a performance, plays Louis Bloom, a would-be news cameraman whose lack of conscience and rabid ambition make him brilliant at his chosen career.

The vaulting ambition and shoot-for-the-stars bravery of this latest film from the director of The Dark Knight and Inception is to be admired, but its attempt to cover life, the universe and everything in nearly three hours is rather enervating.
Visually dull and stuffed with so many characters that none is allowed to breathe.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Love, Rosie is a cheery, sweetly funny will-they-won't-they teen rom-com that rolls on through the more complex twenties of Rosie (Lily Collins) and Alex (Sam Claflin) as their friendship, which began aged five, teeters on the cusp of love.
Produced by Guillermo del Toro, the film has the baroque wackiness of his tastes and the artistry is magical.
Zabriskie Point is a both a thriller and a doped-out dream-capsule of the revolutionary hippy movement in California.
This logging drama is as turgid as the mud that surrounds the forest camp in 1930s North Carolina, despite the fragrant presence of Lawrence as the newlywed Serena in swell silk gowns and jodhpurs.

Those of us expecting the intelligent character development of Band of Brothers, The Pacific and even Saving Private Ryan will find this to be little more than a display of five archetypes in a tin can.
