Unfortunately, when Downey is not centre-stage the drama becomes leaden, sentimental and utterly improbable.

It's one of those Steinbeck-style stories of migrants, poverty, desperation and hope, a heartbreaking picture of men who still believe they are living the American Dream in broken-down trailers doing grim, unhealthy jobs.
I assume that BjÃ¶rk: Biophilia Live was more thrilling in concert than on film, or else half the audience would have been asleep.

The personal, often achingly sad and heroic accounts are intercut with news and handheld footage from the rebellions and a hefty and rather obvious dose of quotes and stills from previous revolutionary leaders.
The film is a tonal nightmare, lurching uneasily from hang-'em and shoot-'em cowboy comedy to gruesome vignettes from the lives of frontier women.

The series now brings chaos to real-life museum director Neil MacGregor's London domain and along the way reveals what happens when characters from those disputed Parthenon bas-reliefs strut their funky stuff.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Kenner's punchy documentary... claims that many of the libertarian nay-sayers rolled out on mainstream American television to spice up "scientific" debate have little knowledge of the subject. What matters, it seems, is how loudly you shout

Boring? Absolutely not. Strangely revealing, meditative and funny? Yes, as passengers reveal themselves by costume, silence, chatter and posture, rising up through a hazy, green landscape into the clouds where Manakamana.
The film is exquisitely shot and Macarena Garcia is achingly gorgeous as the fawn-eyed Carmen/Snow White.
Arrietty is a fresh take on Mary Norton's classic The Borrowers, with animated artwork that will have adults enchanted and children gripped.
Take 12 men. Fill their heads with tales of lost Nazi bullion. Seal them in a rusting, secondhand Russian submarine. Submerge beneath the Black Sea. Allow contents to come to a nice, rolling boil.
Wong Kar-wei's The Grandmaster is one of the more exquisite martial arts movies around, as the Hong Kong auteur behind the lyrical In the Mood for Love takes on the legend of Ip Man.

The electronic hijacking of emotions, or perhaps emoticons, is a fascinating subject, but from the off, a voiceover from Emma Thompson makes it sound like this was written by a committee of cognitive psychologists.
Peter Jackson's Hobbit trilogy goes out with not merely a bang, but a 45-minute baroque, virtuoso battle scene that could be an entire tragi-comic film in itself.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The final instalment, Deathly Hallows Part 2, is a bravura duel between good and evil. It's also a cathartic, occasionally clunky nostalgiafest.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Based on Gallienne's one-man theatre show, the film camps its way through flamenco-style dancing, a German spa, sexual near-misses and an English boarding school.
A silly, schlocky, mummy's-tomb horror-comedy.
Kubrick's spaceships are perhaps little more than Airfix models, but he makes them majestic, even awesome in the proper sense of the word.
Endearing, hilarious, and for humans of a certain vintage, tearfully nostalgic.
For fans of swordplay, Kyoto Inferno provides plenty of one-on-one standoffs, meaty-but-elegant mass slashings and even a whiff of courtly love.
movie_title: RurÃ´ni Kenshin: KyÃ´to Taika-hen (Rurouni Kenshin: Kyoto Inferno) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dietrich BrÃ¼ggemann's disturbing drama premiered at the Berlin International Film Festival and is divided into 14 parts, often pale, minimalist tableaux, for the 14 Stations of the Cross.

Why, oh why did the director decide that God should be played by a stroppy 11-year-old boy with a high-falutin' English accent? Any gravitas Exodus might have had goes up in flames, like the proverbial burning bush.
Having Maggie Smith on screen is like biting into a crisp, slightly sour apple. Even when she is playing a woman in her nineties, quilted with wrinkles, the interior is deliciously tart.
What We Do in the Shadows is the vampire mockumentary you've been longing for.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An exquisitely photographed work of serious philosophical heft which tackles some knotty issues: the divide between the intellectual and working classes, older men and younger women, and believers and non-believers.
Unbroken stars the English actor Jack O'Connell as Zamperini and his performance is raw, brave and agonising.
Brando the singing actor and Sinatra the acting singer make a remarkable pair as sharp-suited gangsters and gamblers, along with their "dolls", Vivian Blaine and the English actress Jean Simmons.
Compellingly weird.
With a large dose of Sherlock and a sprinkling of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time, Benedict Cumberbatch is just brilliant in the role of Alan Turing.
Some French humour still eludes me, and A Perfect Plan is one of those rom-coms that irritates more than amuses.
Of Horses and Men is the best Icelandic noir equine comedy I have ever seen. OK, it's also the only one, but I urge you to seek out this unexpected movie.
The teenage Dido Elizabeth Belle is impressively played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw with a tender sensibility and a growing awareness.
A rather lovely cast, including Colin Firth and Emma Stone, is wasted on a story so old-fashioned and repetitive that it feels like Oscar Wilde with a wit lobotomy.
[A] gripping psychological thriller.

Wiseman is fearless about letting people speak long and uninterrupted and the truth is no longer reduced to cheap soundbites. Instead a slow picture builds of a California institution unlike any other.
In Order of Disappearance is an entertaining revenge thriller spawned where Scandi-noir meets Quentin Tarantino.
Each scene is composed like a painting, and frames a comedy as weird and wonderful as the film's title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An exquisitely traced drama of repressed desire, set in 1880 and shot in glowing, graphic black and white.
Coogler's realistic debut recreates Grant's final day with affection, refusing to cast him as either saint or sinner.
The always luminous Marion Cotillard has Two Days, One Night to get her job back in the harsh economic and social climate of this latest film by the Dardenne brothers.
[A] supremely silly and pleasurable action movie.
Mystery Road is a detective story that unspools with languid menace on the widescreen of the Australian Outback.
If I Stay is a teenage drama so soppy it needs to be wrung out every ten minutes.

The mother lode of the horror genre, this German Expressionist movie is directed by Robert Wiene and presents a full smorgasbord of pop-eyed terror, lunatics, murderers and possessed somnambulists in its eerie shadows.
movie_title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Das Cabinet des Dr. Caligari) (1920)

movie_review_blurb: In Obvious Child, stand-up comedian Jenny Slate plays stand-up comedian Donna Stern, a Brooklyn hipster who puts absolutely no filters between her most intimate, embarrassing thoughts and her shtick on stage.
The problem is that most of the high drama takes place secondhand on grainy war video and the domestic story is rather flat.
Watching GÃ©rard Depardieu's mostly naked performance in Welcome to New York is like being trapped beneath a vast, flabby Lucian Freud painting for two hours.
Moebius gains full marks in the "hard-to-stomach" category for bonkers Korean auteur Kim Ki Duk.
[An] atmospheric thriller.
Self-indulgent, amateurish and often out of tune -- enough to put you off art itself.
Charming.
Fans of the eccentric Jarvis Cocker will delight in Pulp: A Film About Life, Death and Supermarkets.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Two perfectly good young actors -- Craig Roberts and Charlotte Ritchie -- die a thousand comedy deaths as an up-and-coming folk duo on tour.
movie_title: Jolene: The Indie Folk Star Movie (Benny & Jolene) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Canadian serial-killer-hunt script is less satisfying and heavily signposted throughout, so that even Sarandon's Detective Hazel Micallef seems a bit bored by it and sends out her new deputy (Topher Grace) to do most of the legwork.
In the annals of dystopian young-adult franchises, The Maze Runner is less than totes amazeballs.
[Leduc] remains a small and rather irritating sideshow to the more powerful St Germain crowd, and the focus on her life is surprisingly dull.
Luna is a tonal car-crash, a miscegenation of art-school pretension and countrified Boden midlife crises to a bizarre soundtrack of Spanish guitar.
Marcel CarnÃ©'s black-and-white film of 1939 made radical use of flashbacks for the first time and its noir-ish cinematography gives the crime passionnel a dark tension.
Whatever your opinion of Tony Benn, Will and Testament is a delightful and ultimately moving portrait.
The honeymoon takes place in -- oh, guess -- a deserted cabin in the woods, like a failed Evil Dead.
In these times when all risk is assumed by CGI effects, Keaton's squealing funny, exquisitely timed, death-defying leaps are all the more breathtaking.

Lift to the Scaffold (Ascenseur pour l'Ã©chafaud) was the perfect opening to the French New Wave in 1958, sashaying in to a jazz score from Miles Davis and starring Jeanne Moreau as a mistress-in-peril.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'Ã©chafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Gird your stomach for Cheap Thrills, a bloody but enjoyably ironic horror which enters that queasy zone where Michael Haneke's Funny Games meets a reality-TV bush tucker trial.
One of the greatest sequels ever.
After 70 years in the can... some of the most visceral, detailed and shocking footage of the liberation of Nazi concentration camps is being released.
This modern take on the silent genre has none of the polish of, say, The Artist, but director Janez Burger's attempt has some powerful moments.

Whether or not you love his music, the sheer intelligence and poetry of his lyrics, his hip-swivelling suits, his retro black Jag and achingly cool hair make 20,000 Days on Earth a documentary worth watching.

Only Liam Neeson can wear a brown corduroy car-coat with such menace or give off such world-weary ennui just before going into action. A Walk Among the Tombstones is one of his better films in a while, certainly compared to the Taken series.

With the pungent combination of a script from novelist Bret Easton Ellis, a performance by Lindsay Lohan and direction by Paul Schrader, The Canyons might have been a micro-budget sensation, but sadly it reeks of laziness.
Frank is profoundly weird -- and perhaps also weirdly profound.
Perhaps aimed to be a combination of Desperate Housewives and Belle de Jour, with a lesbian twist, Concussion turns out to be surprisingly bland.
[Egoyan] builds incredible tension and emotion in this thriller by throwing the audience pieces of the jigsaw -- in the wrong order.
The adrenaline-fuelled view from bike cameras descends into crash-porn waiting to happen, as the film luxuriates in its own grief.
Take one teenager. Add raw testosterone. Arm with unquenchable, unreasoning anger. Lock in pressure-cooker cell. Unleash. Roll camera.
How rarely does the cinema reverberate with meaty poetry like this?

There are few films so sumptuous that you almost require fabric swatches while watching -- peachy moirÃ© silks, red brocades, eau de nil satins, lilac-grey velvets -- and that's just the menswear and the furniture.
The Vatican Tapes has presumably been released with Hallowe'en scares in mind, but the movie only induces hilarity, with some of the daftest exorcism scenes you'll see.
The year's first entry in the so-bad-it's-good list is The Time of Their Lives, a dramedy starring Joan Collins that had me in fits of unstoppable giggles.

I haven't been so gripped by a film in a long time, but I'm still not sure if my intense engagement with Elle was for the right reasons. This is a shocking, transgressive, wickedly funny psychological thriller.
Fans of the Welsh underdogs that made good will enjoy reliving memories and Gareth Bale's goals, but there is little here for the general viewer.
A gorgeous, magical, witty pleasure lands in cinemas with this live-action remake of Disney's Beauty and the Beast.
A drama that observes the politicking in the run-up to the partition of India and Pakistan into separate Hindu-majority and Muslim-majority states.
Kelly Reichardt elicits every nuance from her small-town characters and leaves the viewer on the verge of reading their minds.
An ultraviolent revenge movie set in Indonesia, Headshot features endless if inventive martial arts fight sequences and copious spurting fake blood.
The enfant-terrible director Xavier Dolan is at his most irritating in It's Only the End of the World.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Best's fame had percolated to the farthest corners of consciousness, beyond soccer to stardom. And that was his curse, and his blessing.

This movie chronicles the hours before the bombing and the manhunt over the days afterwards, often in forensic detail, combining traditional crime-thriller drama with real CCTV, news and mobile phone footage.
A film that's as clunky as its title.
Fences is the most classical piece of drama in the best picture line-up for this year's Oscars, with outstanding performances by Denzel Washington and Viola Davis.
Prevenge is a daringly bonkers horror-comedy by the writer-director Alice Lowe.
The story of a nuttily disguised father stalking his uptight business executive daughter is surreal and screamingly funny, but also a tender dissection of their relationship.
[Tommy's Honour] stars Peter Mullan as Old Tom Morris, in the true-life story of the man who created the Open Championship.
The White King never quite fulfils its initial promise as a dystopian young-adult adventure set in a future police state.

Kirsten Johnson has created a resonant and revealing kaleidoscope of her life behind the camera on films from Bosnian war documentaries to the Edward Snowden film Citizenfour and even a portrait of the philosopher Jacques Derrida.
With slow-burning, stomach-squeezing panic Rebecca Hall delivers a superb performance in Christine as the real-life American television reporter Christine Chubbuck.
Directed by M Night Shyamalan, the horror-thriller is full of plot holes, but McAvoy's joyful and menacingly lunatic performance papers over most of them.
Dancer is filled with breathtaking, gravity-defying athleticism as the dancer Sergei Polunin leaps from a poor childhood in Ukraine to principal at the Royal Ballet in London.
While the latest special effects are grade A, the plotting and character development is that of a B-movie. This Kong desperately needed a rescue mission to save the script from mediocrity.
This is a small, soulful film that has two stars: the feisty Spanish actress Anna Castillo and a vast, gnarled, thousand-year-old olive tree.
John R Leonetti's film shamelessly exploits the Manson Family murders.
This is a fascinating documentary on Gertrude Bell, the English explorer, writer, diplomat, Arabist and possible spy, who was a contemporary of TE Lawrence -- but much less well known.
Loved the book, but grew increasingly lukewarm about the film.
The result is a lush, silken, erotic, disturbing, beautifully photographed drama of betrayal and passion.
While the actual event must have been heart-stoppingly tense, the film is without suspense, and is cack-handed and mundane, with a paint-by-numbers voiceover from Matthew Goode.
Oh what a cheery, trashy car crash of a movie we have in Fast & Furious 8, which does, once again, exactly what it says in the instruction manual in the glove compartment.
Sadly, this wedding farce fails to bubble, thanks to unfunny dregs of a script written by the Duplass brothers.

The talented director Pablo LarraÃ­n, who brought us a slice of political myth with Jackie, is back on his Chilean home turf with Neruda, a wacky semi-biographical take on the radical poet and senator Pablo Neruda.
The intelligent, deliciously repellent Raw stays with you long after the sight of a nice trainee vet snacking on a fellow student's severed finger has gone.
The joke starts well, but the formula gets repetitive.

The manic energy of the original 1996 film has sporadic outbreaks in T2: Trainspotting, but director Danny Boyle is in a more melancholy mood and the story is freighted with self-referential nostalgia and flashbacks to the early days.
The talents of three great actors -- Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman and Alan Arkin -- are lazily squandered in a rehash of a pensioners' bank heist story first made in 1979.
This may be ideal for a school trip for children starting to learn Spanish because there's plenty of Harry Potter-style adventure that makes the subtitles almost unnecessary.
movie_title: Zipi y Zape y el club de la canica (Zip & Zap and the Marble Gang) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Those little blue men in poky hats and long white underwear are back in a garish, irritating shoutfest.

"We cling to memories as if they define us, but they don't. What we do is what defines us." Discuss this oft-repeated line from Ghost in the Shell, with reference to Scarlett Johansson's digitally corrupted memories.
The action is lengthy but well constructed, particularly a sequence on a wood-panelled steam train, but the torture scenes and occasional severed toes may try some viewers.
This intimate, revelatory documentary about the lives of seven teenage girls in Brooklyn, New York, was shot over three years by Jenny Gage and her cinematographer husband, Tom Betterton.
Sonia Braga is wonderful as a retired music writer who lives alone in a gorgeous old apartment by the sea in Recife, Brazil.
Imagine Alien remade with a giant calamari and you have some sense of where Life is heading in outer space.
Two and a half grandiose but curiously flat hours of jungletastic screen time.
In a double whammy of satire, Get Out upends all the expected tropes of the horror movie and gives middle-class white liberals a thorough skewering.
Nixon is superb as Emily Dickinson, the 19th-century poet who, along with Walt Whitman, took American verse into the modern age.
[Jackie Kennedy] is played to perfection by Natalie Portman.
[A] trashy action movie in the vein of the Fast and Furious franchise, which features the same star, Vin Diesel. Humans rather than vehicles do the daft stunts here, however.
This exuberantly daft teenage comedy has some similarities to The Inbetweeners but with a kinder, gentler wit.
[Mathilde is] played by the captivating French actress Lou de LaÃ¢ge.

100 Streets stars Idris Elba and Gemma Arterton, leading one to hope that this drama set in a square mile of Battersea might be gripping. Instead the film feels like a slice of a soap opera, dredging up every London clichÃ©.
Like Freaky Friday with a dash of heavyweight gender politics.
There's just something a little too smug and obvious about it all.
Richard Linklater: Dream is Destiny will fascinate fans of the director of Boyhood and the Before Sunrise trilogy.
A visual feast of a documentary that describes how artists from Chagall to Kandinsky to Malevich rose in tandem with the Russian Revolution in 1917.
movie_title: Revolution - New Art for a New World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Street Cat Named Bob contains the feline performance of the year, as the ginger tom Bob (playing himself) becomes the unexpected mascot and saviour of a homeless busker.
The grand designer Tom Ford has even grander designs on the cinema nowadays.
It seems as box-fresh as a pair of white high-tops and as powerful and funny today as it was in 1991.

Good news: the beasts have been found, and they are indeed fantastic. JK Rowling delivers a magical universe as chiaroscuro as ever, but with plenty of slapstick and surreal hilarity in Prohibition-era New York.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The "starfish" reference is milked heavily and becomes sickeningly obvious.
A promising first feature from Chanya Button -- there's nothing harder than generating a few laughs.
This Disney drama manages to avoid patronising sentimentality with an uplifting and punchy look at the conflicts faced by 14-year-old Phiona.
The documentary Sonita tells the inspiring and disturbing story of a smart, funny 14-year-old Afghan refugee in Tehran who wants to become a rapper.
The 3D bombardment of tiny, squeaking, pink and blue-haired trolls may prove trying for some parents, although a few good one-liners keep the momentum going.
Patrick Shen has made a fascinating documentary with In Pursuit of Silence, which stops the viewer short in the horrendous cacophony of the modern world.

Seen nowadays it is a kitschy, retro scream. Yet as dinosaurs and giant sea-turtles roam the volcanic earth in One Million Years BC, this is also a chance to appreciate the early work of the great special effects pioneer Ray Harryhausen.

Tom Cruise does what Tom Cruise does best... he races cars, delivers bone-crunching punches, leaps from roofs, busts government conspiracies, breaks out of prison, predicts when phones will mysteriously ring and grinds his manly jaw.
Even storks must move with the times.
As an exercise in the unbelievably cool, DA Pennebaker's documentary on Bob Dylan's 1965 tour of England is unparalleled.
The zombie movie takes the bullet train in Train to Busan, a smart horror that contrasts the hyper-cleanliness and efficiency of South Korean life with bloody, neck-biting chaos.
It is directed by Greg McLean and has an energetic performance by John Gallagher Jr as the unsplattable hero, but we've seen this Battle Royale or Hunger Games scenario too many times.
In the queasy area between torture porn and a perverse art installation comes We Are the Flesh.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from the traditional spaghetti set-up of conflicts that will unfurl and be resolved with good cheer around the turkey, David E Talbert's film has a rather moving backstory about the death of the family matriarch the previous year.

This documentary might be better titled Day Zero, because it features a doomsday scenario in which cyberwarfare shuts down the electricity grids and other networks of entire countries, using computer malware.
Fans of Alejandro Jodorowsky's brand of inspired lunacy will be delighted by Endless Poetry, while others may find the latest from the Chilean director more endless than poetic.
A heart-searing drama that slides effortlessly from real life to animated tales to a monster hewn from a yew tree (and some top-notch motion-capture CGI).

In terms of sheer sun-kissed pulchritude, Black Orpheus was like nothing seen before when it exploded with its bossa nova soundtrack in 1959, winning the Palme d'Or at Cannes and the Oscar for foreign film.
However glorious the cast, almost nothing can rescue a Christmas cancer movie, or certainly not one this tonally deaf.
It's not a good premise, but at least the actors try hard in EugÃ¨ne Green's comedy-drama, filmed with arty formalism.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With a childish pink bow in her hair, Aisholpan proves to be the most unexpected heroine: small, smiley, strong as a mountain pony and filled with quiet determination.

Whether you find Martin Scorsese's Silence a pilgrimage or a penance will depend: this is a demanding film, poised on a fulcrum of belief, which tells of the epic spiritual and physical journey of two Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan.
Enjoyably gory and wry.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Body-swap movies such as Freaky Friday always make for good comedy, but Your Name, a gorgeous young-adult animation from Japan, takes the concept into more delicate, dreamlike territory.
Towering like a stick-man over the rest of the cast, K-2SO provides most of the laughs in this portentous voyage into that same old galaxy far, far away.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly Stone wanted to tell it like it was with Snowden, and unfortunately that has already been done better in the tense, minute-by-minute fly-on-the-wall documentary Citizenfour.
A terrific teen comedy with the traditional feel of John Hughes's Sixteen Candles and Pretty in Pink.
In Black Souls the Italian mafia is leached of all glamour in a tale of three Calabrian brothers that grows stranger and more compelling by the minute.
The doctor's investigation leads to an exploration of the collective burden of guilt in the run-down town of LiÃ¨ge, but the film is rather dull.
In Disney's latest refreshing take on the princess genre, Moana is a feisty, sea-voyaging chieftain's daughter without any pink satin in sight.
Obviously only one man could play such a solid figure of American heroism: Tom Hanks.
A complex Korean horror with the surreal village feel of Twin Peaks.
The Incident opens promisingly... [but] falls into a woozy, boring soup.
Well-dressed but highly improbable.
A screen adaptation of John Donnelly's acclaimed play.
There are some funny scenes, including a blind date in a cafÃ© with the brother of a veiled woman who is not allowed to speak for herself, but the comedy often falls flat in a simplistic script.
The combination of cute furry animals and the horror of the Warsaw Ghetto makes uncomfortable and unfortunate viewing in The Zookeeper's Wife.
This film, directed by Michael O'Shea, is less a horror movie than a coming-of-age tale as Milo meets an equally troubled neighbour, Sophie, played by Chloe Levine.
Artists including Mick Jagger talk about their backing singers -- and the soundtrack is, of course, heavenly.
No one wins in this ambiguous, accomplished film, which ends by burdening the audience with a secret that none of the characters will ever know.
It's all a bit improbable, but Dolan -- who claimed never to have watched any Hitchcock before filming -- pulls off a Master-of-Suspense Psycho-drama, down to the scraping, disturbed violins.
The film is more downbeat than tense, interweaves animation sequences, and perhaps worked better in the original novel.
The subject is important and timely, but gets an over the top, melodramatic, thriller treatment.
Perhaps one of the Ten Commandments should be "Thou shalt not make an Old Testament epic".
British director Ayoade's second film is jam-packed with witty references, from cheesy sci-fi soap operas to the long-suffering men who populate the Coen brothers' films.
Liev Schreiber and Romola Garai struggle to find chemistry in their Mars rover, while Olivia Williams keeps her exasperation at full throttle.
While rich with image, the film's plot seems to be chasing its own tail and the result is more boring than tense.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The words "low-budget found-footage horror film" usually signal disaster... Not so for The Borderlands, which turns out to be a smart, funny and genuinely spooky movie, and British to boot.
The director is Mohammad-Ali Talebi and the writer is Abbas Kiarostami; they prove that great film-making is possible with the simplest of tools.
It's Gleeson who gives the performance of a lifetime as the priest.
With his slicked-up quiff, turned-up jeans and revved-up attitude, Dean instantly achieved icon status.
The insightful and cracklingly funny story is an antidote to Hannah Montana and the shallow Hollywood teenagers on the Disney Channel, obsessed by their French manicures.
Wasikowska strips herself down to basics to take on the tough role, and does a fine job, down to the handling of runaway bull camels.
We Are the Freaks is a teen movie that declares its intention upfront to subvert the genre and, unfortunately, fails.
There is no great revelation and the documentary can be a tad lumbering, but Bown's photographs are a glorious gallery trip from a cinema seat.
Without being sentimental, the drama is incredibly moving as the muted light plays over young faces that are about to face the unknowable evils of the adult world.
Around the 20-minute mark in War for the Planet of the Apes a bizarre and wonderful thing occurs. You, the viewer, start to feel like a monkey. No, really.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Filmed at whisker-height, this charming documentary enters the daily lives of the many street cats of Istanbul.
Director Biyi Bandele adapted the book, which was superb and gut-wrenching, but the film turns turgid and shies away from showing the true horrors of the war and is the poorer for it.
An outstanding candidate for the worst film of the year.
Directed by David Leveaux, this film of the stage show is clunky, with sudden close-ups that seem out of place.
The result is a tad predictable.
The tale is fascinating, not just for cycling enthusiasts, but connoisseurs of the human condition.
Imagine the television series Friends with a lobotomy, and you are near to comprehending the crassness of That Awkward Moment.
Unfortunately, the cast is wooden, the script crunchy with clichÃ© and the budget too tiny for even an appearance of the enemy.
This is as fresh as it is self-indulgent, an intelligent piece of navel-gazing. The film loses momentum in the last third, but if this is his calling card, Nance is a young film-maker worth watching.
Sometimes a character punches through the screen, beyond the film containing him. Matthew McConaughey's performance as an HIV-positive cowboy in Dallas Buyers Club is one of those moments.
George Clooney's simplistic wartime art heist movie staggers between parody and sincerity, failing at both.
The director's enthusiasm for the medium cannot be underestimated: warplanes loom from the screen, machineguns splatter in your face, and spectacular flaming flyovers over the Volga abound.
This is Nordic-noir sex, enveloped in a film as complex as it is unforgettable.

The great photographer Richard Avedon curated the titles and exquisitely coloured stills of Hepburn in the latest collection from Givenchy, and each one is poster-perfect. The plot, such as it is, is full of lighthearted fun.
Directed by Jalil Lespert, the film has a peculiar voiceover from BergÃ©, and eventually peters out in a mess of petty jealousies, drugs and illness.
As the Palaces Burn is a documentary on the heavy metal band Lamb of God, and obviously a must for their fans.
movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film is hamstrung by the novel's structure, unsure whether to be a 12A-certificate family outing, or to luxuriate in morbid irony.
The neo-realist film's genius lies in a slow undertow, inexorably dragging the audience from laughter to tears.
Discerning travellers and Wes Anderson fans will luxuriate in the glorious Mittel-European kitsch of one of the director's funniest and most exquisitely designed movies in years.
A surprising reassessment of troubled times.
The Stag tries to play on its Irish comic charm and falls flat.
Suzanne's youthful lightness and hope is constantly crushed by events, and her attraction to the wrong men.
Perhaps you need to be a lover of the original series to fully appreciate this latest effort.
With Salvo, the first-time Italian writer-directors Fabio Grassadonia and Antonio Piazza have created a Mafia thriller that takes a surprising turn from business into salvation and miracle.
The film was a run-for-the-door screaming wrist-slitter for me, but I sat through it on behalf of hardcore Gabriel and Genesis lovers, just in case anything interesting happened. Nada.

While Eastwood provided agonised, end-of-era minimalism as an ageing shooter forced to reload one final time to feed his children, the Japanese version leaps off into wild tangents and indulges in seeping wounds and spurting gore.
Andrea Arnold's new film, American Honey, throbs with raw teenage hormones and sheer chutzpah in a 21st-century version of On the Road.
Julian Assange is less than delighted by Laura Poitras's intimate documentary, filmed over six years with the co-operation of the controversial founder of WikiLeaks.

Thompson and Gleeson are a class act, in a relationship so stale and stiff they cannot even hug during their grief, and the chance to take positive action, however dangerous, begins to bring them back to life.
Brad Pitt stars as the deluded but determined four-star US army general Glen McMahon in this satire on the late days of the war in Afghanistan.
Pattinson makes you root for his character from the start.
This is an international melting pot of a movie, with fresh and surprising ingredients.
Sofia Coppola's American Civil War movie, The Beguiled, turns out to be a comedy as floaty and insubstantial as the dresses that her seven Southern belles wear.
With Noah Baumbach directing, Sandler pulls off a performance as one of the Meyerowitz siblings that gently reveals his character's insecurity and irritation beneath a shroud of laughter.
Todd Haynes's glorious celebration of a boy's own and a girl's own adventure really does leave you wonderstruck -- and in my case, weeping discreetly during the final scenes.
In this vision of industrial insanity humans have become minuscule cogs in the vast machines they serve, day and night.
This latest take on the Arthurian classic is epic in many ways, none of them good.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: FranÃ§ois Ozon is a master at taking apart the French chattering classes, but here he attempts an almost classical piece of film-making in black and white, French and German, a tangled tale of love and friendship.
I blanched slightly at Wonder Woman's almost two-and-a-half-hour running time, but the film raced by -- perhaps because every clichÃ© was subverted by the freshness of a female lead.
It might have worked as a collection of DayGlo YouTube music videos, but the story of an alien abduction -- or perhaps just an Ecstasy-fuelled fantasy -- turns into self-indulgent ennui.
It's a magnetic performance from Kendrick, at once lost and angry, agonised and tender.
This is a horribly misguided attempt to dramatise a meeting between Ian Paisley and Martin McGuinness during talks leading to the 2006 St Andrews agreement, which brought peace to Northern Ireland.

As the world's urban population grows by more than one million every week, so does the resonance of this documentary about a New Yorker who campaigned in the 1960s against the inhuman and brutal scale of new housing.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While the canine performances are impeccable in A Dog's Purpose, this family movie is more of a dog's breakfast in terms of construction and tone.
Its setting on the imaginary isle of Todday off the west coast of Scotland lends itself to gorgeous colour photography and the gentle, subversive wit of the 1949 version has been left intact.
Some comic moments, but no surprises, and a twee ending.
Pugh is superb in the role: a powerful potion of rebellion, determination and lust.
If you're looking for a popcorn lobotomy, and I mean that in a good way, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 is the space comedy for you.

MÃ¤ki is played by the small, sinewy, mildly puzzled Jarkko Lahti; the wonderfully warm Oona Airola plays his fiancÃ©e, Raija. The black-and-white film pays careful attention to period detail and character, and less to the blood, sweat and tears.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli MÃ¤ki (HymyilevÃ¤ mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You are, frankly, astonished that in the nearly four decades since Ridley Scott's first Alien burst spectacularly out of John Hurt's chest, this aggressive face pack of a creature... is still flourishing cinematically.
Nothing goes right for Oscar, or for this comedy, which seems like a student project, and not fully formed.
This elegiac, dreamlike drama set on the Sea Islands off South Carolina in 1902 has an iron core of painful history
Your pulse rate slows to the rhythms of lost rural life at the start of The Shepherd, but by the end it has hearts racing in a western-style stand-off.
One might be tempted to have a few cynical thoughts about Spider-Man: Homecoming, were it not for the puppyish form of British actor Tom Holland in the red-and-blue superhero onesie.
This is one of the most important -- and gripping -- documentaries on the Second World War and its aftermath.
movie_title: The Sorrow and the Pity (Le Chagrin et la PitiÃ©) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: A hit of speed and cartoonish amusement, smoothly chauffeured on to the screen by Edgar Wright, the man behind Hot Fuzz.
Its pleasures and wit stand the test of time. Plus the cinematography is flat-out fantastic, like David Hockney's pool paintings made live.

These four short films are really aimed at committed worshippers of the revolutionary art critic and writer John Berger, and will be somewhat puzzling -- or perhaps appetite-whetting -- to those coming fresh to the subject.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a toss-up between Kleenex and the sick bag at first, but later on the plot veers into improbably stupid territory and it's best just to bail out altogether.
The quietly revealing tale from the director Sunao Katabuchi follows the childhood and arranged marriage of Suzu, an "ordinary", but utterly resilient girl, who also has a talent for drawing.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the wake of the Grenfell Tower fire, this new documentary about the parlous state of social housing in Britain takes on grim relevance.
movie_title: Dispossession: The Great Social Housing Swindle (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The search for the Holy Grail reaches peak insanity in this wild, redemptive ride through two men's interconnected lives.
[Pryce] is horribly let down by a predictable paint-by-numbers script and some overcooked supporting performances.
I am usually a fan of Cousins's curious projects, filmed ingeniously on near-zero budgets, but the thin gruel of this film failed to resonate with me.

This Thai drama begins with the testimony of a survivor of the Thammasat massacre of protesting students by the government in 1976, and spirals into something woozy and strange, an investigation of the process of film-making itself.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As this drama begins... the British prime minister is silhouetted on the horizon, a hunched, rotund figure, with his black Homburg, overcoat and cane, giving perhaps the first sign that this film will take the iconic and turn it into clichÃ©.
Ballerina is an animation that's ideal for junior balletomanes.
It struggles to fill the big screen, either emotionally or visually, and after a while Harrelson's say-it-as-it-is persona becomes irritating.
French acting gentry Marion Cotillard and Louis Garrel fall in love in a mountain sanatorium in the 1950s in this slightly wan drama from Nicole Garcia.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to Hurt's extraordinary performance -- soft-skinned, red-lipped and determined to fight politely for his rights -- it still seems relevant and not just an exercise in nostalgia.

This documentary from the director Claire Ferguson gathers gripping testimony from 12 Jewish survivors, now in their eighties and nineties, who were mostly teenagers in Nazi death camps, or who escaped to join the partisans hiding in forests.
While there are a few plot holes, Palmer and Riemelt sustain the tense arthouse thriller.
[The Mummy] begins with B-movie fun, but descends into an impenetrable soup of battling pixels.
This Chinese-American production may make decent television for children on a rainy day, but there's not enough thrilling action or comedy for the big screen.
It is a righteous, religious film that almost bludgeons audiences with its powerful message, and is the product of the one-man-band of Nate Parker, who wrote, directed and plays the lead.

Spike Lee's latest is an extraordinary confection: a satire written in verse, set to rap, gospel and hip-hop music, based on an Ancient Greek play moved to Chi-Raq, a nickname for present-day Chicago.
Cillian Murphy, Jamie Dornan and Toby Jones star in the Second World War-set Anthropoid.
A paranoid thriller about two well-heeled Islington couples who find they are having first babies weeks apart and live in the same building.
Two words. Marge Gunderson.
The casting cannot save a slightly ho-hum story that crosses the Atlantic badly.
What a gorgeous and enlightening documentary Hitchcock/Truffaut is, even for the non-cinephile.
This gentle comedy, set in the midst of Glasgow's ice cream wars, still resonates with its superbly observed characters.
In The Propaganda Game, the wildly surreal world of North Korea gets a fresh viewing, this time from the point of view of the only foreigner who works for the Communist government.
Perhaps the most emotionally intelligent film you will see this year.
Sometimes a scene leaves your critical faculties floundering, and so it was in Grimsby as Sacha Baron Cohen and Mark Strong retreated into an elephant's vagina to escape machine-gunning assassins.
Peck's performance, in tortoiseshell glasses and a cream linen suit, is mesmerizing and serious.
Pride and Prejudice and Zombies does exactly what it says on the tin, rather entertainingly too, especially if you have seen one too many tasteful television adaptations of Austen's work.
Tender, moving and exciting for kids (and their secretly tearful parents).
The Survivalist is a cracking, tense drama set mostly in a wooden shack in the backwoods of Ireland, in a post-apocalyptic world not far from our own, where oil and other resources have run out.

Smith takes on Omalu's Nigerian accent and too-perfect grammar with confidence, as this man with eight university degrees and an iron respect for science finds his research being crushed by the dollar-rolling might of the NFL machine -- and even the FBI.
We see certain films so you never, ever have to, and The Green Inferno is one such atrocity.

One might hope that the long-awaited sequel Zoolander 2 would be a biting, lunatic satire on the present selfie-regarding fashion industry. Instead, poor Stiller turns out to be An Actor Who Can't Direct So Good.
Cranston is good, very good, here, but let down by a meandering drama that lacks cojones.
[The cast members] have great comic timing, but this film mostly fails to make use of it.
Janis: Little Girl Blue is a fascinating, flower-powered documentary on the short life and long-lived music of Janis Joplin.
Goosebumps is a surprisingly funny adaptation of the RL Stine children's monster-book series, with Jack Black playing the ghoulish writer and Dylan Minnette the boy next door.
Even the idea that Fifty Shades of Grey might require parody seems ludicrous.
The writer-director Magnus von Horn keeps the nature of John's crime a secret from the audience for most of the film, which becomes an increasingly desperate and unlikely device.
The eco-message is rather vague, the villain not particularly villainous, and the jokes fall flat.

The Pearl Button is a piece of visual poetry that meanders along the waterways, coastline and history of Chile, coming into sharp and horrifying focus on the atrocities of Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botÃ³n de nÃ¡car) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Miles Ahead riffs on the life of Miles Davis, improvising around the facts available, but somehow still reveals the essence and spirit of the man and his music.

Peter Greenaway's latest, Eisenstein in Guanajuato, may not be up everyone's street, and even fans may find the self-indulgent longueurs towards the end of the film too much. Still, the premise is interesting.
A wild feat of visual imagination.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hirokazu Koreeda's Our Little Sister is a gentle, lyrical, beautifully shot story of three sisters who take in their 14-year-old half-sister, and find their past is not what it seemed.
As tender and revealing as it is completely bonkers.
Some films exist entirely on their own terms, while others benefit from a bit of backstory.

What a very fine cast T he Huntsman: Winter's War is proffering: Jessica Chastain, Charlize Theron, Chris Hemsworth and Emily Blunt. And what a fine mess the first-time director of this fairytale prequel makes as he squanders their talents.
As a pistol-packin' cowgirl in fringed leather trousers, Day is terrific, an object of athletic awe and irrepressible good cheer.
A visual meandering through the scarred city which unearths painful history -- and poetry.
Less a classic and more a curiosity, Wild Orchid is a cult piece of Eighties erotica that was panned at the time but now is weirdly fascinating.
A peculiar and gripping study of parental grief.
Directed by Scott Graham, the story has a timeless quality, the spiritual and the bucolic intersecting with unnatural desires fed by the proximity of the community.
Acknowledged as the Bosnian director Emir Kusturica's masterpiece, Underground is a hallucinogenic comic romp through Yugoslavia's troubled history over 50 years.
Curiously deranged but powerful.
My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 is as stale as last year's baklava, an attempt to cash in on the 2002 movie without updating some very old-fashioned tropes.
A thriller that fails to thrill.

This superhero-smorgasbord directed by Zack Snyder melts into an electric soup of CGI. Effects are so overused that any conviction explodes in a giant fireball -- indeed endless fireballs. The result is an enervating two and a half hours.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: High-Rise manages to be a work of towering insanity and a searing comment on the decadence of present-day London. Rarely is a period film so of the moment.
More a curio than a straightforward classic, Nicolas Roeg's Eureka is beyond weird.

Risen is a sort of Sunday school special, an Easter adventure starring Joseph Fiennes as Clavius, a war-hardened Roman tribune who ends up investigating the disappearance of Jesus after the stone is mysteriously rolled away from the Messiah's tomb.
Directed by Jacques Audiard of A Prophet and Rust and Bone, the drama comes at a timely moment, showing the struggle of refugees entering a less-than-welcoming country.
Hail, Caesar! is a playful romp through Hollywood's golden studio age when egos and cigars were vast and backlots were filled with divas, communists and salacious gossip.
In many ways this screwball comedy is a precursor to Some Like It Hot, but with a silkier wit and some gorgeous fashions.
Be ashamed, Robert De Niro, be deeply ashamed of every scene of Dirty Grandpa, a sleazy comedy spurting unfunny jokes from a lost time.
An insightful, moving drama.
Depp has never been short on menace, and he is so unpleasant as Bulger that his usual gangster charm never kicks in, leaving the audience cold.
The lads are daringly bonkers, and their horses are suicidally brave -- or misguided.
Epic seems too small a word for the sweeping ambition and romance of Doctor Zhivago.

An exquisite film by Todd Haynes that delves into the lost arts and crafts of a raised eyebrow, a smouldering glance, a sharp intake of breath, a brush of a coral-polished fingernail, a pulse of expensive scent and looks that could thrill.
Beginning with its punning title, Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans proves to be a clunky film about the actor's obsession with motor racing, and his incredibly expensive attempt to make Le Mans.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What is it like to grow up as the son of a senior Nazi, with atrocities on your family conscience? In this powerful documentary, the British lawyer Philippe Sands meets two men living in the shadow of the Third Reich in very different ways.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mr Calzaghe is the antidote to the Rocky-style comeback trajectory of every boxing movie.
All hail to the humongous Hunger Games franchise.

While the 2000AD British "brotherhood" put staid American efforts such as Superman in the shade, this film is mostly a series of middle-aged talking heads nostalgically discussing a past that we barely glimpse.
The Perfect Guy is a lazy retread from the Fatal Attraction department of stalker movies.
Do kids really want to follow a plot about intergalactic trade embargoes?
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: This is a children's film made by adults who think they knwo what children want.
Warriors documents the splendid journey of a cricket team of Masai warriors.
Fathers and Daughters is a sentimental pile of tosh

While Robinson Crusoe on Mars is more a kitsch curio than a classic movie, there is much entertainment to be had comparing this 1964 story of "a lone astronaut pitted against all odds beyond this Earth" with The Martian.
With a title that already reeks of failure, Bradley Cooper's turn in Burnt as a Michelin-starred chef making a comeback from coke-induced burnout is best avoided.
One of cinema's classic love stories.

In the adroitly observed The Closer We Get, a family crisis turns into an autobiographical detective story when the film director Karen Guthrie returns home to care for her mother in the seaside town of Largs in North Ayrshire.
Saoirse Ronan's expressive face carries this tender romance across the Atlantic, from small-minded Enniscorthy in Ireland to big-hearted New York.
Quentin Tarantino's dirty, funny and unpredictably violent genius powers True Romance, directed by Tony Scott.
The latest incarnation of The Jungle Book -- almost half a century after Disney's much-loved musical cartoon -- is a stunner.
Serious, shocking and occasionally stomach-churning.
Intermittently funny.
A conventional but gripping dramatisation.
Exquisitely beautiful and harrowing meditation on war and love.
Frontier epic takes cine-suffering to new levels of agony and - most importantly - veracity.
A shot of box-fresh blood.
Directed by Ramin Bahrani, Quaid gives a fine performance, but the drama reflects the flatness of the land it features.
This is one of the French new wave master's seminal films, a satire on the making of a Hollywood-style movie that exploits Bardot's femme fatale Camille with no less aplomb than Hollywood itself.

Sleeping With Other People is an updated -- and raunchier -- take on the When Harry Met Sally rom-com premise: can a man and a woman ever be best friends, or will there always be just a troublesome frisson of attraction?
Eddie Redmayne makes another astounding transformation in The Danish Girl, after his Oscar-winning turn as Stephen Hawking.

As Balor, [Damian Lewis'] sour, guilt-ridden Protestant work ethic clashes increasingly with that of his wife Aislin, an ethereal Celtic creature seemingly washed in from the sea, played by Andrea Riseborough.
Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid are outstanding as Cathy and Frank Whitaker, a perfect couple with a decidedly imperfect love life.
Snoopy and Charlie Brown: The Peanuts Movie will serve young children well as a Christmas outing, but whether it serves the child that remains in all of us early Peanuts fans is another question.

This seventh movie is a humongous piece of cinema -- all that a sequel should be and more: a nostalgic homage to the 1977 original, coupled with intergalactic, warp-speed, panoramic blockbuster action, and a new heroine in the form of Daisy Ridley's Rey.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The result is entertaining, although the stakes are rather low.

The documentary maker Jennifer Peedom went to explore the Sherpas' world and village life -- and their exploitation, which means they may be paid $5,000 for a summer's work, while visitors pay $75,000 for a single death-defying trip.
If only By the Sea were hilariously bad, I could recommend it for star power alone. But this is a film stuck in the doldrums.
Hector is the best Christmas film out this year.
The whimsical romantic comedy directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet burst through the language barrier to become an international success.

The Forbidden Room is a fun ride for cineastes and was much fÃªted at festivals. Whether it will appeal to mainstream taste with its insane mash-up of B movie-style parody, silent-movie intertitles and jungle vampires is anyone's guess.
In Grandma, Lily Tomlin is entertainingly and terrifyingly eccentric as a ballbreaker of a grandmother.
The most debilitating thing about this whole soggy mince pie of a picture is that it's narrated by a dog.

Although there is amusing sexual tension between French corporate cost-cutter Eloise (Annelise Hesme) and sacked music company marketer Tom (Kris Marshall, who was in Love, Actually long ago), there are no surprises here.
Friend Request is a thoroughly unpleasant and somewhat laughable horror movie with a warning to young folks at its core: be careful whom you friend on Facebook.
[Reeves] appears to only have two expressions: sad face and need-a-pee face.
Think of Arabian Nights as a cinematic box set: three boundary-bursting, exuberant, empathetic films from Miguel Gomes, which build up into a portrait of present-day Portugal.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 1 - The Restless One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 1, O Inquieto) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [A] humdinger of medieval powerplay.
Theroux takes his usual sideways, faux-innocent look at the Church of Scientology, which was recently thoroughly eviscerated in Alex Gibney's Going Clear.
An elegiac, raw, painful film that explores the strangeness of growing up gay in Miami's black community in the 1980s.
Suffused with gorgeous cinematography, the sharp-sweet drama The Fencer is Finland's foreign Oscar entry and a pleasure to watch.

I do like a film that opens with a mission statement, and... Cat People starts thus: "Even as fog continues to lie in the valleys, so does ancient sin cling to the low places, the depressions in the world consciousness."
Drowning in her own sorrow and mascara, Emily Blunt plays the title role in The Girl on the Train in this much-anticipated transfer to the screen of Paula Hawkins's bestselling thriller.
The story is not merely the usual business of courageous men escaping a towering inferno, but also of the battle between corporate greed and blue-collar [workers].
You have to hand it to Daniel Radcliffe for being willing to try anything for his art, but playing a fart-powered corpse in Swiss Army Man was perhaps a step too far.
Daniel Ragussis's direction is clunky -- endless news montages of Hitler fans, Ku Klux Klansmen and skinheads marching the streets do little to build the story.
Unfortunately, the film takes an awed, almost hagiographic view of McLean, whose acquaintances included the Kray twins and Ronnie Biggs.
The film version is pure Mills and Boon coupled with Grand Designs, even down to signs that say "20 days to Chelsea build" as the clock ticks.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople has been a huge audience favourite at festivals this year and you can see why, with its brand of dark New Zealand humour, coupled with a boy's own adventure story that goes not merely off the rails, but off-road and off-grid.
It's a haunting, delicate portrait of childhood, with a father who oozes mystery.

Despite being equipped with hi-tech GoPro-style cameras and GPS, as well as a drone, the investigators lose their grip almost immediately, but it's an hour before any frights ensue, and those are mostly jump-scares.
The patriarch is Arquimedes Puccio, played brilliantly by Guillermo Francella, his piercing, pale-blue eyes gazing from another, darker world.
David Oyelowo and Rosamund Pike fall truly, madly, deeply in love in London in 1947.
Arterton is perfect as Mrs Catrin Cole, simultaneously luscious and reserved.
A smartly crafted heist thriller that quietly peels back the layers from its macho male characters to reveal the pain and tenderness inside.

The real story is less about the sci-fi and more about the weirdness on Earth, a woozy dream of greed and alcohol and betrayal, as the gentle Newton is preyed upon by hucksters and the American government.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Affectionate and hilarious.

It's certainly fun, and a spectacle to behold in IMAX, but if you're going to remake the 1960 classic, which starred Yul Brynner and Steve McQueen, you need to make a cinematic cavalry charge into the territory of modern sensibilities.
Less Close Encounters of the Third Kind and more Linguistic Encounters of the Academic Kind, this is a sci-fi movie with intelligence, cerebral and emotional.
It's full of perfect Tarantino moments, with meta references, B-movie sleaze and a sheer sense of fun.
Baden Baden has a breakout performance from SalomÃ© Richard as Ana, a 26-year-old woman looking for direction.
The material is uncontroversial to say the least, but hugely enjoyable with some remastered live performances that were previously drowned out by screaming girl fans.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sour Grapes tells how wine stopped being a drink and became a tradable commodity in the madness of bull markets.
In The Blue Room, Mathieu Amalric directs and stars in an updated version of the 1964 Georges Simenon novel about adultery and death in a small town.
A glorious flight of the imagination.
There's not a laugh to be had.
The Childhood of a Leader signals a fascinating new talent in art cinema: the actor Brady Corbet.
Asterix: The Mansions of the Gods treads tired territory in this ninth animated film based on the French comic books.
movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (AstÃ©rix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a long interview, interspersed with news footage, but what makes it compelling is the smooth, wary intelligence of Begg as he answers for his actions -- and others' suspicions -- which resulted in him being tortured in prison.
The film is pretty unconvincing, despite a good performance from Rivers.
I am always a sucker for the eye-gasm of a fashion documentary.
What can you say about a Hollywood comedy that features a "comedy" second-act rape sequence in a massage parlour?
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The director George Amponsah embeds himself in north London to unravel the background, and the subjects of his powerful documentary are Duggan's best friends.
A French rom-com starring Jean Dujardin as a handsome, charming architect with one little problem: he is 4ft 5in high.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme Ã  la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An outrageous, wickedly funny, 1930s fascist version of the Shakespeare play starring Ian McKellen as Richard of Gloucester.;
Born to be Blue is perhaps a too-clever fictionalised take on the life of the jazz trumpeter Chet Baker, although Ethan Hawke's performance as the musician is as compelling as it is painful.
Watson gives a serious, determined mien to her character.
From the Thai arthouse director Apichatpong Weerasethakul, whose Uncle Boonmee won the Palme d'Or at Cannes a few years ago, comes another strange swooning dream, Cemetery of Splendour.
A powerful debut from the writer-director Helen Walsh.

What's entertaining here is that they leave the usual Amityville surroundings for a damp and mouldy council semi in Enfield, London, in 1977, where the Hodgson family is being plagued by a poltergeist.

Free State of Jones stars Matthew McConaughey, with his smooth Southern lilt and cool demeanour, as Newton Knight, a battle-weary Confederate soldier who deserts, deciding that he no longer wants to fight for the rights of slave owners.
Summertime is a gorgeously shot film by the French director Catherine Corsini that swoons over a lesbian love affair between CÃ©cile de France and Izia Higelin.
A nuanced, funny and agonising dissection of a woman's life after her 25-year marriage hits the skids.
A simultaneously pretentious and amateurish luvviefest.
Almost Holy is a deeply disturbing and shocking documentary portrait of life at its lowest ebb.
This is less about resurgence than regurgitation on a humongous, eye-gouging 3D scale.
The adult fairytale is a freakish, hybrid, disturbing creature, mostly forgotten in these days of Disney sanitisation, but Tale of Tales resurrects the genre with surreal humour and gothic horror.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The "fish out of water" theme plays out to Buster Keaton-style excess in the hilarious and adorable Finding Dory.

The adventure was not merely sexual, however, but a radical rethink of film language: the characters' motivations were left opaque and unexplained, and the story never quite resolves itself -- rather like life.
Mother's Day is less a film and more a selection box of clichÃ©s.
As timely as it is timeless, Gianfranco Rosi's portrait of a year on the Italian island of Lampedusa is stunning.
Loach is a man of principle and stubbornness, and he keeps on coming out fighting.
movie_title: Versus: The Life and Films of Ken Loach (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie enjoys all the politically incorrect pleasures of the Seventies with a knowing chuckle.
This is the zingiest Austen adaptation you'll ever see, with the usual pastel palette and slow decorum abandoned in favour of acid colours and acid remarks, which keep the audience in stitches.
It's a bit like Synecdoche, New York or The Matrix, but the mystery is not gripping enough to keep the viewer marching around the MÃ¶bius strip of the film.
Despite the high tech, which seamlessly blends Rylance on to a 24ft body, the film has an old-fashioned, over-whimsical feel.
Think of an episode of Scooby-Doo, add product placement by Chanel, plus a soupÃ§on of French existentialism, and you have some sense of the sheer bonkersness of Personal Shopper.
This Ealing comedy is Robert Hamer's directorial debut - he later went on to make one of the best in the genre, Kind Hearts and Coronets. The seeds of that wit are in Pink String and Sealing Wax.
We discover what made the phone app angry birds incandescent with rage in The Angry Birds Movie, repurposed for children in this cheerfully ironic adaptation.
From his hunched, put-upon shoulders to his nervous, rapid-fire delivery, Eisenberg gives us vintage Woody.
The movie is delightful melodrama, but it has an Wildean bite and is, of course, all about the importance of being earnest.

Lucile HadihaliloviÄ's film is part sci-fi, part body-horror, part feminist revenge, but delivered with slow, measured lyricism so that the knowledge of what is happening, unsaid behind the scenes, creeps coldly down your spine.
Are you #TeamCap or #TeamIronMan? If this question makes any sense to you then Captain America: Civil War and its superb action sequences will bring you untold joy.
What's striking now is how utterly modern it is in structure.
A heavenly musical filled with down-to-earth humour.
Ruth Negga slips into gentle Southern mode to play Mildred, opposite a bullock-like, stubborn Joel Edgerton as Richard in this film by Jeff Nichols.

The film squirms with that very British comedy-of-embarrassment, and is rich in daft penis jokes, but with a poignant core that explores Anna's relationship with her twin brother and an eight-year-old kid next door.
[A] taut and surprisingly witty thriller.
There are a few plot holes and some stiff acting, but the threesome is compelling as the gals get their guns and their revenge.
Wiener-Dog is a mordantly funny tour of the human condition seen from the low-slung position of a sausage dog.
Director Matthew Miele brings a pinch of irony and conflict to this gorgeous waft through the perfumed and bejewelled halls of the world's most famous jewellery store in New York.
The Wave is a small-town Norwegian disaster movie writ satisfyingly large.
[An] insightful documentary.
The B-list superheroes have been unleashed upon the world, with their very own cult B-movie, and it's quite a lot of fun.
There is nothing [Vinterberg] likes better than creating his own Big Brother house, trapping his protagonists and teasing out their weaknesses, falsehoods and quiet heroism.
There is a palpable sense of dÃ©jÃ  vu, despite being in the capable hands of director Paul Greengrass once again.
It's a strange kettle of fish, this adaptation of Arthur Ransome's beloved Thirties children's book, but bizarrely enjoyable for its sense of freedom and derring-do.
Alan Bates is at his handsome, wickedly charming peak in A Kind of Loving.
The film stars Gary Oldman as Sid and Chloe Webb as Nancy, both dialled up to 11 on the acting-ometer, perhaps as manic and irritating as their characters were.
It delivers a satisfying and amusing dollop of sci-fi comfort food.
The film is bracing at first and then allows itself to slip into schmaltz.
In K-Shop, a little shop of horrors emerges in a kebab takeaway.
While the apocalypse continues in the real world, Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie remains gloriously Botoxed in a time that austerity forgot, still drenched in Bollinger and bad behaviour.
An early gem from the social realist movement.
Unfortunately the sleight-of-hand thrill of live magic becomes an unconvincing sledgehammer on the screen: layer after layer of trickery and rushing about lead to exhaustion.
This is not just a tale of struggle and courage, a relearning of the world's signals, however, but also a moving portrait of family life.
It is as sordid as it is entertainingly preposterous, as the director makes a misguided attempt at mansplaining the fashion world of Los Angeles.

The new, bigger, bustier Ghostbusters is a rollickingly funny delight, paying homage to the classic film but rebooting it with four female protagonists who have the same laconic, ironic wit as the original men.
This bullwhip-cracking action-adventure launched the series starring Harrison Ford.
Driven by the brave performances of its two young leads, this tender and emotionally resonant film thoughtfully challenges our ideas surrounding death.
Fresh, funny and boosted by Anna Faris' superb comedic performance, this raunchy rom-com registers as a surprising delight.
Movie goers likely will look over The Grace Card's entertainment value to focus on this simple prescription for how to gracefully love your neighbor.
Its glossy looks, first-rate playing and famous pedigree will be cat-nip to book-groupies.
Steven Spielberg's masterly, high-minded recreation of Abraham Lincoln's long-shot battle to get the 13th amendment outlawing slavery through a hostile Congress.
The images of North Chile's lunar landscapes sing - if you can stand the mercilessly long takes.
movie_title: De jueves a domingo (Thursday Till Sunday) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing if not predictable.
An ambitious love letter to a Louisiana way of life that's being literally washed away.
No one does the pitchblack flipside of funny like Wilder, and 1960's The Apartment is the darkest he ever made.
Dardenne brothers favourite JÃ©rÃ©mie Renier is uncannily good as the tightly wound star, as well as a dead ringer for him.
Frears seems to be in something of a slump, and his giddy, surface-skimming adaptation of Beth Raymer's memoir about her trajectory from stripper to bookie isn't reversing the trend.
Noel Clarke, who co-scripted and co-stars, doesn't get any Kidulthood-style grit going, though Crichlow's gutsy performance has you rooting for her.
A pitch-perfect period setting can't compensate for the presence of the lithe but terminally listless leads.
Its stagey mix of East Is East-style father/ son conflict and bouncy bedroom farce is endearing, though a tad stereotyped.
The characters' all-round unpleasantness, and the film's merciless mirth-making with their failings, keeps things buoyantly, bleakly funny.
Legendary chef Ferran AdriÃ 's philosophising about pushing new food frontiers is fascinating, but barely glimpsed, so keen is the film on recording the appliance of science to innocent ingredients.
Well-crafted, wellintentioned and well, just a tad dull, Redford's radical-chic-road-trip will appeal to the Senior Railcard crowd.
Despite some affecting moments, the lumbering Parkland feels more like a well-researched magazine feature than an involving drama.
It's all a pretty obvious metaphor for the icy plunge that the Icelandic economy took recently, but is none the worse for it.
What knocks it out of the park is the combination of Ephron's insights and Reiner's matchless comic chops.
Seyfried and Sarsgaard excel in a biopic that focuses on the hard times rather than the hardcore, and leaves you feeling that there's a lot more to say.
As well as the film's almost documentary realism (it's required viewing for shipping personnel), here the brief but telling extras show off Lindholm's dedication to accuracy.
The actors excel, particularly Levya, whose turn will knock you sideways.
What keeps the show on the road are the three male lead performances, which are commendably stripped-down and honest.
Witty, wry, and just a little bit scattershot, this good-natured satire takes on cinema's last taboo with small-screen plotting, but big-screen gusto.
A tasteless, breathless Hello-tastic romance that plays fast and loose with the facts. Any more creepily reverential, and it would be curtseying.
Undeniably hard-going for non-history buffs, but well worth the sweat.
movie_title: Walesa. Czlowiek z nadziei (Walesa: Man of Hope) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Once-upon-a-time tales about Elizabeth Taylor ordering 200 pairs of mink earmuffs, or Yoko Ono's Christmas Eve $400,000 furs-splurge, can't compensate for a lacklustre storyline about the famously intricate Chrimbo shop windows.
Ambitious in its span and powerful in its recreation of tumultuous times, this is a skilful dramatisation and a worthy celebration.
Like the Abscam con, the film is a convincing confection, so well played that we don't care if it's the real deal or not.
Moving, if heavy-handed, it's an emotional walkabout with real heart.
This charming comedy show [Cher] at her warm and supple best.
A sly true-crime drama.
Andrea Arnold's stark, defiantly naturalistic new version succeeds brilliantly in injecting the shock of the new into this well-thumbed English classic.

A pedigree cast, fun premise and punchy dialogue make Bullock's return to romantic comedy look a great catch, and Reynolds is sharper than a diamond solitaire. Pity, then, that its penchant for sentimentality makes it miss congeniality.
Kids will enjoy the gobby tween attitude and energy, but the paper-thin plot and extraneous 3D antics don't provide the solid laughs of, say, Diary Of A Wimpy Kid.
Despite top-notch visuals and versatile voice-work from Ty Burrell's doting doggy dad and Alison Janney's monstrous social worker, it lacks the Up-style warmth to be best in show.
There's more than a whiff of Festen and Altman in first-time director Christopher James's frantic, enjoyably overstuffed funeral drama.
Crunchier than an ICF coshing and about as subtle.
Kids will be hooked, but adult viewers may yearn for something a bit racier, with fewer cute field-mice and more fox fucking.
But Ninagawa's obsession with image-making saps the story until the movie, like its heroine, is merely handsomely mounted.
There's continuous chuckles rather than a barrel of belly-laughs in this warm winner. A sweet, slightly shambling buddy-movie that will please those who prefer gags to gagging.
3D heats up a cooling franchise nicely, alternating the familiar friends-forever 'aw' factor and chucklesome comedy chases with some ace in-your-face visuals.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: CuarÃ³n's spirited footie fable is a game of two halves, buzzing with balls, bimbos and black comedy, but ultimately unable to bring home the trophy. Bernal gets man of the match, no contest.
A film of small gestures closely observed, it's surprisingly unsentimental, despite its heart-tugging qualities.

An extraordinary story receives a decidedly ordinary treatment in this worthy weepie, which can't get either Ford or Fraser to catch fire. Heartstrings get tugged and tear-ducts tickled, but it's more Lifetime movie than movie of a lifetime.
No melodrama, no thriller twists, just Trapero's camera sticking to his lead actress like sweat.
Martin Freeman's chippy, cocky artist is riveting, as tender to dying wife Saskia (a knowing Eve Birthistle) as he is tricky with his militia patrons...
Filled with brusque tenderness and dusty beauty, director Warwick Thornton's first feature is a fine and moving example of outback neorealism.
Prepare to have a bawdy, taboobusting good time. Just don't expect it to resonate anywhere except your funnybone.
Catherine Breillat's move from arthouse provocations to ponderous period dramas continues with this austere, slyly experimental adaptation of Charles Perrault's grisly classic.
Ward weaves a deft hidden family tragedy, but you'll see the revelations coming a country mile away.
Kiarostami keeps us guessing, while Binoche drives the movie with a performance that earned her Cannes' Best Actress award.
Studded with surreal and unexpectedly tender touches (kamikaze cows, an elegantly lovestruck horse), this is plastic and fantastic.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The real standout here is newbie Laura Neiva who plays Filipa with a convincing mix of minxy manipulation and blundering vulnerability.
Like Secretariat himself, the film is a glossy, big-hearted slow- starter, but lacks his ability to power home ahead of the competition.
Both plotting and playing are a bit ragged and the visuals are telly-tastic, but the film's fresh, unvarnished take on male friendship is altogether winning.
movie_title: The Be All and End All (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A cross-cultural sequel that's as gently comical as the first was satirical. Despite lashings of Eastern promise, it's as British as a chip butty.
Witty scripting spices up a sugary scenario, giving this fluffy family comedy some adult-pleasing bite. It ain't Shrek, but it ain't dreck either.

Meek's Cutoff is simultaneously cerebral and astonishingly cinematic, a historical road movie that stretches the inhospitable landscapes and marginal living of Wendy and Lucy in intriguing directions.
A swoony, enjoyable, old-time romance whose best acts are a period-perfect Pattinson and a playful pachyderm.
The breathless account of Sassoon's '80s stint as hair-product mogul would have benefited from some September Issue-style detachment, and ironically, the whole film could do with a good trim.
Underneath Third Star's classy cladding, which camouflages its maudlin streak and conventional melodramatic underpinnings, there lies a TV movie first and last.
Inhabits Glee and High School Musical territory without mustering their wit or creativity.
One can only regret this writer-director's decision to cram so much material into the mix that some fine understated performances, and much of the film's emotional impact, are obscured along the way.
The result is a sturdy, often suspenseful piece, but one that delivers less than it promises.
With explicit sex and penetrating philosophy, this erotic odyssey requires close attention and an open mind.
Certain Women's whispers are more penetrating than most film's shouts.
Smartly spoofy rather than sweetly nostalgic, this distractingly star-studded jaunt is fast and funny, but short on emotional punch. But a good time awaits for kids and long-time Muppet-lovers.
Though it never shakes off its stage-play origins, it's a touching piece, clear-eyed about the temptations, disapproval and tragedy the couple endured.
Deliberately uneventful and domestic, it's a fiercely private piece given extra poignancy by Akerman's own death last year.
Sarandon is magnificent in a film that's as full of heart as it is blatant Apple product placement.
Acting honours go to Bening, but it's Mills' wit and originality that make this story-lite dramedy shine.
The pacey script is as slickly engineered as a Mercury rocket to include girl-power fun, romance and against-the-clock launchpad crises.
With explicit sex and penetrating philosophy, this erotic odyssey requires close attention and an open mind.
Biller never lets deadpan fun drop into crude spoofing. Prepare to be bewitched, bothered and bewildered.
Beatty's fine, but this is no Hail, Caesar!
This feels more like a glossy, beefed-up tribute, tweaked for inclusivity, than a fresh take on a much-loved piece.
Both smart political primer and tense cautionary tale.
Johansson emanates a dogged vulnerability that's supremely human.
Wry but not dry, its nimble use of archive footage and chewy interviews expands the film into a thoughtful examination of what (and who) cities are for.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Rachel Weisz's wily-or-winsome widow crackles with dangerous allure, but can't gee up this sedate mystery.
A precise and elegant fable, which uses magical realism to wind its elements together, The Red Turtle hints rather than hollers about the emotional bond between man and animal.
You'll need a tissue, not a calculator, for the tender-hearted finale.
This is as gorgeous as an oil painting, and about as lively. But Jean-Pierre LÃ©aud effortlessly summons up the iron ruler inside the failing man.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing a rom-coma into the romcom, this smart, sweet and highly personal love story finds a winning formula.
Its attempt to cram in both origin story and follow-up adventure makes it a long haul for the target tinies.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This offally appealing arthouse tale of elusive love in an abattoir is a prime-cut, for the strong-of-stomach.

movie_review_blurb: The playful use of archive, animation and dramatised snippets of Blahnik's hard-partying past give the film a fun, fizzy feel.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Showing how animal families are driven by the rhythms of night and day, this sometimes awe-inspiring doc is visually stunning.
A chilly, elegant and thought-provoking futuristic family drama ...

The film's sympathetic eye ensures it doesn't exoticise the family's plight, or dip into poverty porn. Drunken brawls, pissed-off johns and vicious catfights are simply day-to-day eruptions here, blowing in and out of the motel like the Florida weather.
Pattinson plays a blinder in this gripping, gritty grindhouse-meets-arthouse heist movie.

You may have to hold your nose to get through some of it, but He's Just Not That Into You is dangerously slick and attractive enough to suck you in regardless.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)
