movie_review_blurb: No amount of Clooney mugging or priceless Spacey glowering can fill in the gaps left by this meandering screenplay.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fantastic Mr. Fox is Anderson's best film since The Royal Tenenbaums, and perhaps his funniest ever.
A soothing bath of Hollywood tropes and cliches.
Weitz's efforts result in a movie that's a little less insular and self-involved, though in the end, still probably one only the true fans could love.
It's all about the action.
There's something in the way that Old Dogs is brazenly, proudly lazy that makes it truly reprehensible
It's brisk and exciting and exuberantly obvious filmmaking, but it knows how to light up every bloodthirsty pleasure center in your brain, and does so with gusto.
The film is a triumph of visual imagination over any story or substance, over-directed and over-acted and completely absent a beating heart.
Pretty much the Marley and Me of this holiday season, except in the place of an adorable yellow lab there's adorable Robert De Niro.
Brothers sometimes feels unnecessarily Hollywood, but there's a surprising amount of truth in there as well.
Lovers of Hate, very simply, deserves to be seen in any way possible.
Bridges inhabits Bad fully, and cleverly uses our decades of fondness for him as an actor to give us a way to connect to his troublesome character.
The movie works, maybe because of all the easily digestible lessons of racial tolerance and sports movie cliches.
Avatar is as old-fashioned and romantic as Titanic, and thrillingly, just as wonderful to watch.
Self-righteous and obnoxiously condescending.
It's hard to imagine why you'd want to pay to be talked down to and coddled like a baby.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A shambling, lovable mess of a movie that never manages to keep its boundless imagination in check.
Guy Ritchie combines his kinetic direction with the limitless charms of Downey Jr and Jude Law to come up with terrific entertainment that's equal parts brains and brawn.
The lethal lack of humor keeps the audience from getting any pleasure out of it.
Even moviegoers with a soft spot for uplifting family drama will have a hard time sitting through this one.
Apparently Martin and Zwart really did want to make a movie this aimless and derivative, aware that their target audience of children won't know what they're missing.
An uneven, stolidly traditional comedy.
It takes a whole lot of chutzpah, and a real lack of imagination, to make a movie like New In Town in 2009.
A classic adventure with its heart and its sense of whimsy in all the right places.
Presents characters as concepts rather than actual people, and deals much more with the theoretical consequences of war rather than the actual human toll.
A feminist horror movie, an updated version of old-fashioned exploitation that lobs a few gentle barbs at the way we are now.
By not necessarily glorifying the activists while agreeing with their cause, writer-director Stuart Townsend creates a multilayered portrait of an eventful five days.
A sweet and simple story that aims to be no bigger than it is, a shaggy dog fable about dreams and the transformative power of even the worst movies.
Completely enjoyable and largely fun, but almost instantly forgettable.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An indie for people who love indies.
Schwimmer just doesn't have the directorial wit to elevate the intermittently amusing script, and none of the cast seems dedicated enough to raise the bar either.
A movie that lives and dies on its gimmick, and when you figure out that all it's doing is toying with us, there's nothing left worth watching.
If everyone is going to be out there seeing a Tyler Perry movie this weekend, I don't mind that they're seeing this one.
As a star Clooney is in his element, but as a director he's strained.
Nim's self-reliance and Alex's journey to open herself up to the world are inspiring, even when the circumstances that get them there are lackluster.
It's not as fast-paced or silly as it ought to be, mostly because Lee doesn't really seem to know what he's doing behind the camera.
Though the group members are hilarious and their stories effortlessly touching, the clumsy filmmaking and manipulative editing muddle what should have been a simple human story.
Chaos may make for an interesting life experience, but onscreen it results in a messy and unfulfilling movie.
An above-average comedy that makes better use of funny women than virtually any other movie has in years.
An indie comedy done without excessive pretension or quirk.
So lost within its own ideas of satire and its own ridiculous plot, War, Inc. never really figures out anything to say.
Contrived and too serious for its own good, it's hard to imagine any distributor loving it so much they want to let the rest of the world see it.
So muddled and self-important that none of its characters, not even with Moore's ferocious performance, can take shape.
What Happens in Vegas is evidence that putting two attractive stars together onscreen is not enough to make a good, or even passable, 90 minutes of entertainment.
Narnia may never escape comparisons to Middle Earth, but it's on its way to creating its own satisfying vision of a fantasy world.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Pineapple Express is just damn funny.
In short, Sex and the City the movie is everything Sex and the City the show ever was, as rambling and superficial as it is cunning and loveable.
The movie isn't exactly a breakthrough for Sandler, but is a nice reminder of his expansive talents and kinder instincts that only occasionally win out in his films.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you like your epics sweeping and bloody and real, Mongol may be the best you get for a long while.
A drug-tinged love letter to summertime.
For all his complaints recently about being misunderstood, it seems it's Shyamalan who simply doesn't get us.
Breslin is sparkling in the lead role.
A classic story told traditionally and well: Hollywood at its classiest, if most predictable.
Journey to the Center of the Earth 3D feels like a visit to Frontierland, with boat rides, mine carts, and one heck of a log flume.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sweeney Todd is often considered Stephen Sondheim's masterpiece; it's too early to say, but it may be Tim Burton's as well.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film is so stuffed with visual poetry and moving turns of phrase that it practically takes flight.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You get the feeling that a darker and more clever Despicable Me may have existed at some point before the studio defaulted to the safe side.
Without real characters or a fresh take on drug addiction, Candy has little to recommend it for anyone who's seen The Basketball Diaries or Requiem for a Dream.
Manages to snuff the spark that has made Charlotte's Web so beloved over the years.
[McAvoy] carries lightly what could have been a clichÃ©-ridden clunker and helps create an utterly winning romantic comedy.
Even with nothing more redeeming than a lot of good one-liners, Unconscious has a charm that your ego, superego and id can all enjoy.
[Uses] talented kid and adult actors and a remarkable attention to detail to perfectly capture the delicate, minute rites of passage that define growing up.
A lot of pop-music montages--great soundtrack, by the way--stand in for actual acting or directing, and there's not a single thing here that hasn't been done better before.
Manages to be both an unsatisfying human drama and a confusing sports movie at the same time. Fans of both genres will be disappointed.
Jarrod, Lily and the rest, while odder than just about anyone you know, are recognizably human, with motivations and histories that dig deeper than most comedies are willing to go.
Gracie is no failure, but its mishmash of sports tropes and melodrama doesn't satisfy the way it could have.
Its honest storytelling and painfully funny moments make up for the thrown-together feel.
What's remarkable is that [Baichwal's] footage manages to add meaning to the photographs, already so powerful on their own.
A slightly patchy tapestry that tickles about as much as it annoys, full of unexpected laughs but also some torturous dead spots.
Truly tender, truly funny...a pessimistic, unrelenting take on love that is still a date movie for anyone who wants to enjoy a romantic comedy without feeling guilty about it.
Has its minor charms, but it never gets at the deeper, more interesting side of the fascinating world in which it's set.
Sydney White is no Mean Girls or even Clueless, but 'tween girls could do a lot worse than this sweet, well-meaning fairy tale.
As overlaong and pretentious as its title, The Assassination of Jesse James is worth a look almost in spite of itself.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jones graces the film like an elder statesman.
We Own The Night brims with raw feelings and elegant filmmaking.
It's so daring and so inventive that it feels like a strange kind of treasure.
A generic version of any other dramatic comedy about familial love.
An extremely moving and informative documentary.
So calculated in its sentimentality that it almost feels cynical.
Suffers from an undeveloped script about as much as it benefits from a generous sense of whimsy.
Despite its idiosyncrasies compared to more modern thrillers, it's a fine addition to an outstanding season for movies.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Almost too unique for description; a tour-de-force comedy with tremendous heart.
It might be impossible to love the characters Baumbach gives us here, but they're always worth watching.
It's the clarity with which Jenkins sees it that makes the film extraordinary.
Once the political lines are drawn, Vargas' film becomes richly layered, and builds with greater and greater tension toward its harrowing, inevitable finale.
Making parodies can be easy, but Kasdan, Apatow and their wonderful cast take their jobs seriously.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though Finding Amanda's story reaches a reasonably satisfying conclusion, the empty characters at its center make the whole thing feel like a waste.
A clever, contemplative kind of courtroom drama that utilizes the best of Hollywood filmmaking style to tell a story so strange, it must be true.
Mileage will vary, depending on one's affection for ABBA, nonsensical dance numbers and middle-aged women cutting loose in sparkly outfits.
Dear Zachary's emotional intimacy is its greatest strength, and enough to get it through sections that seem more manipulative than meaningful.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A tribute to a musical era gone by as well as Mac's career, Soul Men is highly imperfect but also hugely enjoyable.
An unambitious romance aimed at grown-ups, it deserves the handful of champions it will find, but probably not the Oscar campaign it's heading into.
A story of coincidences and luck and eventually fate, it's a classic, perhaps cliched tale-- but one that has rarely felt or looked so alive.
An economically told, extremely powerful story.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a romance, Twilight is just subpar-- a more celibate, moodier take on Dawson's Creek or 90210. As a vampire story, it's a disaster.
It sounds like a mess because it is one. A gorgeous, earnest, reckless, and brazenly captivating mess.
Nothing But the Truth is flat and unexceptional, the bureaucratic, talky parts of a political thriller without the action sequences as payoff.
While Milk would be an excellent film any year, coming as it does in November 2008, it is almost unbearably poignant.
A fascinating, worthy adaptation, even when its own cinematic shortcomings dilute its power.
BeyoncÃ© emotes and cries and seduces at all the right moments, but her character obscures what should have been the heart of the film.
Were there any real passion or feeling behind it, The Reader might feel like more than just a space-filler on the inexorable march to Oscar night.
Vital and brilliant, without American Beauty's occasional pretension, it's a shot in the arm for the dull holiday season, a shattering experience well worth having.
Good feels more self-important than satisfying.
A nifty little thriller, entertaining from start to finish, and just weird enough to seem unique.
The Class simply exists as it is, a dispatch from a familiar world that has still never seemed to real.
True to its bland title, it isn't too Puerto Rican for a wide audience, isn't too racy for a family audience, and hell, isn't even too Christian for an audience not celebrating Christmas.
The original 1951 film carried a timely anti-nuclear message, but this film wouldn't dare offend anyone by even mentioning the phrase "global warming."
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despereaux feels hand-drawn but better, cartoony in all the right ways and lushly, perfectly stylized.
Defiance doesn't go beyond the usual tales of valor and virtue, managing to make an amazing true story feel like yet another dry history lesson.
Refreshing in its lack of pomp and circumstance, a movie that exists to be a movie and nothing bigger.
A movie so bizarre the studio is unwilling--or afraid-- to even tell you what it's about.
Great concept, but no one has any idea what to do with it once they've gotten there.
Its small moments of insight don't make up for the overall lack of drama or narrative, but they will evoke all the proper emotions out of an audience with tissues at the ready.
Bride Wars takes every ugly stereotype about women and weddings and dumbs them down even further.
The untold side of the story haunts the frames of this standard-issue biopic.
A couple of Segway jokes stretched to an hour and a half running time.
Taken is brutish and loud and slow in parts, but also undeniably entertaining.
Star Wars fandom has been celebrated in pop culture for decades, but we're still waiting for a movie that captures it with any real level of truth.
I don't begrudge its G-rated vision of 17-year-olds, but I do wish they'd made room for real conflict.
Richly layered like a novel, with themes ranging from entrapment to romance to fulfillment, this smart, beautiful, even funny movie is an unequivocal pleasure.
The action scenes provide their own appropriate thrill. There's no telling why anyone thought this movie was necessary to make, but now that it's here, we may as well enjoy it for what it is.
A big nothing, not even hokey enough to watch for the sake of laughing at it.
Nolan has shown a new way to tell a superhero story, and it may turn out to be the only way to tell a story about heroes in this troublingly amoral time.
Ferrell's Brennan is as dumb as his George W. Bush, as enthusiastic as a Spartan cheerleader, and as convinced of his own importance as Ron Burgundy.
...Burstein takes time to let the kids honestly express themselves; what she finds is both surprisingly and painfully familiar to anyone who has ever survived high school.
If you're willing to accept its flights of fancy and leaps of logic, it's a pleasant enough summer adventure with its heart more or less in the right place.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Swing Vote is the broadest, most meaningless kind of mainstream comedy.
A shiny, buoyant movie about young women that gives them actual personalities and brains
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fred Durst seems so anxious to replicate popular sports movies of the past that he never comes up with anything worth exploring in his own movie.
It's sacrilege, I know, to suggest that a Sundance hit would have been better as a strictly Hollywood product, but a bigger budget might have helped.
Making Traitor something more than a disposable B-movie was possible, but at this point in the release calendar, way more effort than it was worth.
Bangkok Dangerous isn't nearly the ugly, stupid film you might guess based on the poster and Nicolas Cage's hairdo.Bangkok Dangerous is merely average.
A surprisingly timeless story given its hip trappings. It will enthrall teen viewers who imagine such an adventurous, music-fueled life for themselves.
Poppy is almost a real person, waiting for us somewhere in London, humming to herself and wearing her favorite tan boots.
St. Anna is probably too strange and unwieldy to become the classic that Lee wants it to be, but it's a worthy stretch for the director.
An episodic, muddled movie that never quite finds its way.
The Uninvited works better as a Maine travel guide than a horror movie.
Samuel L. Jackson, in top, scenery-chewing form, is probably the biggest liability in Lakeview Terrace.
It's disturbing to think of the millions of teenage boys who will laugh when he insults a girl to get her in bed, or pees in a cactus plant at a restaurant.
The stellar performances, impeccable production design and stirring, though occasionally flashy, cinematography make Blindness worth the suffering it inflicts on its audience.
A road movie with no purpose, and a war drama with no bite.
A movie needs a reason to exist other than to wring tears out of overemotional people.
Somewhere between a cautionary tale and a simple character study, Reichardt's film belongs to that part of all of us that finds hope on the other side of the horizon.
Fassbender's commitment to the role is astounding.
A dressed-up period piece with nowhere to go, a cipher masquerading as a heartfelt piece of work.
The film marches along at its own disinterested pace, rarely explaining which moments might be important than others or even the roles of some key characters.
The movie is simply, stellar, an American parable and moving drama found in an unlikely place.
Body of Lies isn't half bad, sprinkling in well-shot action and some moments of genuine suspense.
Unusual warmth and intelligence makes Bees a cut above the usual sappiness and schmaltz.
Yes, it's a shame no one is making movies like Goonies anymore, but this pale imitation is just as disappointing.
The pleasure lies in being surprised when the movie overcomes its own limits.
The truly committed will find something redeeming in this jumble, but the payoff isn't really worth the slog of getting there.
A satisfying journey that doesn't require too much examination, just an appreciation of the scenery and what it took to get by during this period of American history.
Inception doesn't just dream bigger than most movies even dare, but it leaves the audience feeling inspired to do the same.
With rigorous direction, deeply committed performance and an unflinching willingness to expose raw nerves, Shame is an arty experiment that cuts deep.
It's everything you could ask for from a summer movie.
It quickly becomes exhausting in adhering to its many lessons, all mostly about how women can manipulate the men in their lives to treat them better.
Feels perfectly of a piece with everything else the studio has made-- daffy, self-assured, willing to try pretty much anything, and utterly unique.
A quiet and well-told movie that wears its big beating heart on its sleeve.
The Five-Year Engagement catches a bad case of the meanders and never quite recovers, leaving us to wonder what Segel and Stoller could do if forced into a tight 90 minute runtime
Focused on its razor-sharp execution and ideas rather than its characters, the movie is more of an intellectual wallop than an emotional one.
Battleship isn't the longest or dumbest blockbuster to ever exist, but so soon after bar-raising spectacle of The Avengers, maybe the most pointless.
An uncomfortable mix of comic setpieces and a treacly plot about a dictator who just wants to be loved.
With lots of good jokes and very funny child actors, plus adults who carry the emotional weight the children cannot, Moonrise Kingdom has elements that hold up to the best of what Anderson has done
Sanders has approached a classic fairy tale with a few strong visual ideas and a very game Charlize Theron, and it's almost impressive how little he's managed to make of it.
It's aiming to be both an epic space thriller and a spiritual treatise, and watching it almost accomplish both makes it all the more frustrating.
Lola Versus feels more like a slog through the breakup doldrums than the frothy, intimate growing-up story it hints at throughout.
HIGH School isn't exactly Harold and Kumar-level genius, but it is worth the legal risk.

Lorene Scafaria never nails down a tone for this rambling road trip romance, tossing together some dark humor, some rom-com contrivances and some last-minute sap for an uncomfortable, never quite satisfying combination.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Your mileage, as with any movie crammed with unintentional laughter, may vary, but there are performances and some spectacular fight choreography that ought to keep anyone's interest.
What's probably most impressive about the work Steven Soderbergh does, directing from Reid Carolin's script, is that it's got the glitz and the heavy character study, without sacrificing either.
For the first hour of The Amazing Spider-Man, you'll be forgiven for feeling serious deja vu.
Though Samberg nicely handles his dramatic scenes and eliminates all the shtick you might expect from SNL, Jones is the clear standout.
It's sprawling but undeniably engaging, not quite the blast of clever mayhem The Dark Knight was, but no slouch either.
Ruby Sparks diminishes its own stakes from the start, and nothing that happens in this breezy, ineffective rom-com does anything to improve that.
Farrell is a bland presence at the center of a surprisingly bland movie.
The chance to watch these two veterans stake out a very real relationship on screen, while muddling through a film that doesn't offer a whole lot beyond them.
Perhaps in a second movie Aaron Cross can stand on his own, but for now he feels trapped in the shadow of what came before.
There's a genius behind the silliness in The Campaign, in that a go-for-broke comedy might really be the only way to deal with the reality of modern politics.
With infinite warmth toward its characters, whip-smart humor and a plea for human compassion that feels especially necessary these days, ParaNorman is a movie worth wrapping yourself up in
The Expendables 2 isn't nearly clever enough to operate as an actual action movie as well as a parody of one, but it is a good amount of fun.

It helps to let yourself get lost in David Cronenberg's Cosmopolis, which adapts Don Delillo's novel and clings hard to the inscrutable, arcane language, which very deliberately keeps the audience at arm's length
It probably was fun to drive all these hot cars around California, and make a movie with your friends and sacrifice plot logic for better jokes. But where's the fun for the audience in all that?

Shot through with good humor that balances out the blackness, and performances that liven up even rote plots of revenge, Lawless earns its detours and minor missteps, a late-summer surprise with unpredictable power.
Creates a world so lively and well-wrought I'd happily see a dozen more movies set there.
A people-pleasing Disney "documentary" hellbent on building a kid-friendly narrative, it contains enough stunning footage of the chimps and their jungle habitat to remain engrossing.
Chbosky can't reinvent the characters he created for the screen, but he's definitely done right by them.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else it's a strong argument for Pearce to take on more charismatic leading roles-- he comes so close to rescuing Lockout that who knows what he might do in an actual good movie.
This sometimes manic and very straightforward film won't be for everyone, but it does have a surprisingly broad appeal.
There really is no polishing a Twilight movie, which by design will have to be both silly and terribly boring.
Arthur Christmas, a joyful and tremendously funny spin on Santa as a story of family dysfunction.
It's entertaining enough, but a missed opportunity as well.
A harsh but insightful and often very funny take on what happens when you cling to that popularity well after its value has faded.
Dull and instantly forgettable, a nostalgia trip that takes you nowhere worth going.
A bracing and completely absorbing thriller.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It runs faster, goes bigger, and tells stories better than nearly any action film this year.
Fleet and thrilling and as boundlessly energetic as its hero, The Adventures of Tintin is Steven Spielberg's most purely joyful film in at least a decade.
The movie makes no argument for existing.
Joyful Noise is an honest delight, as corny and occasionally as preachy as a tent revival, but as open-hearted and dynamic as well.
Contraband squanders its tiny bit of goodwill with a hotdogging, "gritty" attitude that's never reflected in the actual story.
A go-for-broke action thriller that only gets more exciting the more grounded and real it feels.
Wearing its heart and ideals on its sleeve, Red Tails is hard not to root for, but impossible to love all the same.
The Grey has exciting ambition and the highest emotional stakes imaginable.

With a sure visual sense despite a clearly limited budget, and most importantly a rock-solid understanding of storytelling, Birbiglia crafts a romantic comedy that's utterly unique, but also satisfying in a primal, familiar way.
A whole lot better than many of the more traditional superhero movies we've seen.
Too naive for the tricky grown-up issues it tackles, but not smart or sweet enough to get away with it.
Less a thriller than an experiment in confusion, trying to rile up the audience by stranding them in scenes they don't understand, over and over until the climax mercifully sets us free.
As likable as Rachel McAdams and Channing Tatum are, their presence is small comfort in a movie with so little else going on.
The 3D conversion isn't going to change your opinion on the movie or give you a whole new moviegoing experience, but it's not bad either.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Cage cuts loose with such campy abandon when he's supposed to be tormented that even Johnny Blaze seems to get this is going nowhere.
A logic-free, utterly joyless thriller that substitutes a wild goose chase for an actual plot
With ace performances from Paul Dano and Robert De Niro as they create a supremely complicated father-son relationship, Being Flynn is a low-key drama full of pleasant surprises

With no narrative drive, characters to care about or stakes of any kind, Project X is so busy celebrating its own debauchery it never manages to make any of it look very fun or exciting. Who knew kids these days could be both so uninhibited and so boring?
Unpredictable and very silly but with real emotional stakes, 21 Jump Street makes up for a shaggy script with a wily, endearing energy that feels like anything but a tired retread.

With plot twists that are hard to swallow and a general aversion to any real conflict, it's a movie with a flow that's easy to slip into , and just as easy to slip out of and forget once it's through.
Though it has the potential for real greatness it settles for ultimate audience satisfaction, which is pretty close to greatness anyway.
It starts feeling like a long series of in-jokes, gags that seemed funny on the set but barely ought to be worthy of a blooper reel.
Just as goofy as the first one, but actually enjoyable this time around.
Please, God, tell me you're not going to waste your time and - more important - money on prepubescent jerk-off humor that reeks of comedic flopsweat and gender-insensitive sexual frustration.
The saddest thing about Jack & Jill is that we allowed Adam Sandler to get to this point.
This big, ambitious, gorgeous, glorious film demands that its audience walk in as open-hearted as it is.
With style and dour charisma to spare, Dredd proves that the smartest way to handle an action plot is often the simplest.
A bittersweet, marvelously effective end of a certain goofy era, when friends banding together were enough to save the world.
Rush's greatest strength is the rivalry that drew Howard to tell this story to begin with, and the gifted actors who bring it to life.
Your mileage may vary on the film's more spiritual elements, but Gravity will make you believe in the higher power of movies.
True stories this remarkable are rare, and movies about them that work this well are even rarer.
About Time is funny and charming as all get out, but its messy core keeps the many pieces of quirk, sentiment and romance from lining up into anything worthy of all the talent here.
Every generation gets their own Romeo and Juliet, but kids these days really didn't deserve this dull, cheapo attempt.
It's nothing new to watch an impressive survival story onscreen, but rare to see it done this well.
The Fifth Estate tries to ape its subject's bravado and innovation to near-disastrous results.
Touches of wit and insight enliven the first half, but Carrie eventually devolves into lackluster modern horror cliches for a souped-up version of the famous finale.
Peirce might have made a fantastic horror movie about horrible teenage girls, but she and the actors alike are trapped within a framework that nobody seems brave enough to break out of.
With Fassbender a blank patsy in one corner, and Diaz and Bardem hot-blooded horror shows in another, none of the actors or characters of The Counselor ever seem to exist together ...

In its strongest moments, it's like spending a weekend with exasperating but beloved friends: full of jokes both witty and dirty, slap fights, heart-to-hearts, and an overwhelming good cheer that only occasionally teeters into sanctimony or sentiment.
This is rigorous Disney hit-making at its finest, but with enough charm to get away with it.

As Oldboy moves on it feels more and more generic, as if a studio grabbed hold of the wheel and turned it into something more resembling a late-90s Ashley Judd thriller than either the original or any of Lee's films.
The lackadaiscal plot, cheesy jokes and lack of originality make Caddy nothing more than a trashy comedy, but at least it's occasionally an entertaining one.
Though The Orphanage sticks fairly closely to a genre fomat, and the plot twists become a little predictable, the film packs surprises all the way to the end.
It's one of the few movies based on a toy with no explicit story behind it. And it is, so far, the only one that's really good.
It's not as lovely as Pixar's best, or remotely as complex in its storytelling, but it makes for a refreshingly simple intro course on modern superhero-movie tropes.
The emotional catharsis of Argo isn't what happens onscreen, but the sheer knowledge that the creaky old moviemaking system has put together something this crowd-pleasing and great.
In an age when more and more movies just feel like stepping-stones toward the next, bigger things, is it so much to ask that it be a good movie all on its own?
Straight Outta Compton earns its place in the pantheon of biopics that are good, just not as great as the artists who inspired them.
For anyone following Watson's slow and steady path toward becoming one of her generation's finest actresses, Colonia is more evidence of the exciting career she's building.
Equals and its recycled dystopian ideas may feel like nothing new, but that's not a problem for the romance at its center, as old-fashioned as Romeo and Juliet and nearly as satisfying.

Idris Elba's ferocious performance alone should be enough to keep Beasts afloat... and the True Detective fans who fell for Fukunaga and his man-bun (now cut short, alas) can see this and know just what a tremendous, ambitious talent he is.

Seth Rogen may have grown up a lot since Knocked Up, but The Night Before still fits precisely into that wheelhouse of raunch comedy with heart. Thank goodness he hasn't grown up too much to make movies like this one.
The Wiz Live! was, wouldn't you know it, actually pretty good.

If you sensed a livelier energy while watching Grease: Live last night, a sense that there was something happening that people were excited to be part of, you weren't alone. FOX's first foray into the live TV musical genre scored huge ratings.

The sorority sisters of this movie aren't fighting for the right to party, but to do it on their own terms; Stoller, Rogen, and company have infiltrated the studio system to make a comedy on their own uncompromising terms.

But while the film sometimes feels busy and scattered, Janney and Robbie are vivid anchors, diving into the kind of complicated, boundary-pushing characters that, let's face it, are usually the domain of men onscreen.
A great film about the American civil rights movement is way overdue. The Butler, overwhelmed by flash and good intentions, doesn't even come close.
The Master is unforgettable, but like the mercurial men at its center, the harder you try to read into it, the more it slips away into the distance.
A movie so lazy that it opens with clips from famous YouTube videos, just to prime the pump for laughs.
It's not the summer's laziest sequel-- that's still Grown Ups 2 by a wide margin-- but it's a comfortable second place.
Pitch Perfect takes what ought to be a story with limited appeal and makes it so hilarious you can't deny it.
As energetic children's entertainment with a twist it works fine, but Frankenweenie has the elements to go further before it settles for something that feels too familiar.
It's both a little too serious and a lot too silly to strike that powerful campy chord.
If only modern American politics were remotely as entertaining.
Skyfall isn't just a great Bond film, it's the character's resurrection.
Flight is a messy return to live-action filmmaking for Zemeckis, but its strongest scenes -- and especially that plane crash -- are reason enough to be glad he's back.
Anna Karenina is a massive, boldly imagined work, the rare novel adaptation that's purely, thrillingly cinematic.
The world created in the movie is so utterly fascinating that I desperately want to see what other kind of amazing, creative tales can be told within it.
It's a movie cinema lovers can rally behind and gawk at forever.
For its occasional moments of excess and unhurried pace, An Unexpected Journey is proof that Jackson still has a knack for stories in this world.
Telling a nearly three-hour story with an ending everyone knows, Bigelow and Boal have managed to craft one of the most intense and intellectually challenging films of the year.
Offers enough endearing goofiness and magic of its own to earn a pass this time.

Jack Reacher errs on the side of taking itself too seriously, and in simplifying the story becomes more of a standard-issue action thriller-- while most of us know that Reacher and Cruise are capable of something more
Gangster Squad is bloody, sloppy and far dumber than it looks, a Hollywood spectacle of slo-mo bullets and explosions perfectly calibrated to be soulless.
A twisty and surprisingly sexy thriller that, despite its heat, is actually about how cold and disconnected the world can be.

Safe Haven doesn't have a whole lot to offer, with a plot so familiar and stars so uninterested in each other, and its resolution only undermines what it's truly best at being-- a cheap North Carolina vacation.
Like the Civil War re-enactments featured in the final action scene, it all looks insane on the surface, but has a mighty power to suck you in.
It's a strange hybrid, and not entirely a successful one, but hey, at least it's trying something different.
Olympus Has Fallen takes a star performance and gallons of fake blood and stretches it into something both captivating and queasy.

In walking the impossible tightrope of violent satire, Bay succeeds by calling up one of cinema's most powerful and least-understood languages: the relationship the audience has with the people onscreen before the film even begins.

Take-flight moments of blockbuster bliss are frequent and consistently spectacular, as Abrams continues to prove his rare gift of combining character, plot, comedy and action into setpiece after setpiece
Cianfrance creates a layered and moving portrait of working-class life, of people trying-- in many of the wrong ways-- to improve lives for themselves and the generations to come.
Large-scale, original sci-fi is a hard thing to come by these days, and despite its familiar story Oblivion does dream up some great ideas
Luhrmann's The Great Gatsby makes enough inventive and fairly amazing choices to earn its outsize existence.
If endless mumbled monologues from Vin Diesel are the price to pay for watching The Rock land a leaping punch to the face, it's worth it.
No movie this blatantly cobbled together ought to work nearly as well as World War Z does.
Really silly, but really fun.
Pacific Rim is shiny and big and eager to please, but its originality can't save it from feeling as derivative and empty as any cobbled-together remake.
Believe it or not, Grown Ups 2 is better than at least one other movie in existence, and that movie is Grown Ups.
At the very least, it proves that Woodley's vulnerable performance in The Descendants was no fluke, and sets up Teller as easily one of the best actors of his age.
Ultimately undone by a whole lot of bad decisions.
To hate 10 Years is like hating the enthusiastic girl who organizes your high school reunion-- can you really be so mean when so much effort was made and a reasonably good time was had by all?
Loses track of the nifty sci-fi idea that is the best thing the movie has going for it.
Surprisingly insightful and funny, an easy watch for indie film fans curious about the next big thing.
David Yates better captures both the playful and solemn tones of J.K. Rowling's writing, making Harry's wildest and most dangerous journey also one of great adventure and growth.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A clever and shiny and deliriously funny take on the classic princess genre
The King's Speech is that rare classy period piece that isn't like eating spinach; it's a treat from beginning to end.
If Rabbit Hole feels a little more neat and contained than a movie ought to be, the performances almost entirely make up for it.
Though the film has no lack of technical skill, what's missing is the spark of imagination
Its plodding pace and sense of perfunctory magic rather than real wit lays bare all the reasons the franchise has never really taken off.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even when the narrative meanders, the phenomenal performances and Russell's dogged interest in them make The Fighter rousing, surprisingly funny, and even heartfelt too.
How Do You Know gets by on witty and realistic dialogue even when its story is sloppy.
Everyone has turned into a gross caricature of a human being, either unbearably mean or lascivious or hammy to the point that you actively root for their demise.
Somewhere is a movie for the Sofia Coppola faithful, the ones willing to look through what might seem like myopia to the truth that lies beneath.
It's not just weary parents who will get fed up with this one; kids will probably realize they've been duped too.
Not nearly funny or weird enough to see with friends after a few drinks, and despite impressive locations doesn't have enough visual appeal to simply watch on mute.
Likely to please no one, neither the comedy seekers drawn in by James and Vaughn's mugs on the poster or the more sophisticated grown-ups who hear the movie is darker than you expect.
Immensely satisfying on nearly every level.
If you're willing to jump into his gleefully hedonistic world, there's a lot of fun to be had.
A messy, ambitious disappointment.
Superbly entertaining, an irreverent and sardonic look at business of product placement and how completely corporations can, and do, control the movie business.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's so much joy crammed into the film that there's no time to notice the lack of depth.
An utter mess.
happythankyoumoreplease goes down easy and charming without a bit of weight or meaning.
Sanctum aims for a kind of stern-jawed, gobsmacking action adventure, but gets hopelessly tangled in its own silliness and ineptitude instead.
The logic seems to be that the bright colors and half-hearted attempts at plot will be enough, but even the youngest kids know better by now.
A surprisingly compelling window into a phenomenon that, at its core, is as old as pop itself.
For all that I enjoyed I Am Number Four while I was watching it, I'm also confident I'll have forgotten I ever saw it within the year.
Unknown never establishes any identity or juice of its own, content to crib successful elements from other thrillers and present them with a shrug.
A wild, messy disappointment.
A brisk and affecting slice of sci-fi that allows room for optimism and even God.
Both better made than Twilight and far less entertaining, Red Riding Hood could easily lure the same crowd, but doesn't offer much to anyone not entering the theater ready to swoon.
A sharp and endearing take on the workplace comedy, anchored by veteran Roger Michell's sure-handed direction and a luminous lead performance from Rachel McAdams.
There is no dust or pretension here, just a great story impeccably shot and acted, and a film impossible to shake.
By casting a raft of magnetic actresses and focusing his work around their talents, Perry gives his film a power beyond the melodramatic twists and flat-footed dialogue.
A soppy, disorganized melodrama with a lot of big ideas and virtually no significance.
A generational milestone.
It's like a friend you're not that fond of sobbing sloppily on your shoulder.
A bunch of guys past their prime punching and kicking each other and pretending its for our benefit, when its really just one last self-congratulatory hurrah.
When the tangents are this funny, you eventually start looking forward to the next one.
An effective and frequently satisfying indulgence, but not nearly as much as the book was.
The result of filmmakers who take seriously their job of cutting loose like kids.
Shaggy and likable, but not lovable, The Switch is the rare romantic comedy that's actually about and made for adults.
The Last Exorcism's cynical take on faith is worse than pandering, it's ineffective.
Aims for both the heatstring-tugging power of sports classics like Hoosiers and the kind of gritty indie drama you might normally see Rockwell in, but falls well short of both.
The flashy visuals tend to say a lot more than the story itself.
Going the Distance occupies a happy medium where we don't necessarily really live, but like to think we could. In short, it's better than you're expecting.
Affleck's directing outshines the writing he did with Peter Craig and Aaron Stockard, but there's a lot to like here.
Audaciously weird and scary and go-nuts psychotic, Black Swan is, by any measure, a tour de force.
Easy A is zippy and clever and far more original than you thought a high school comedy could be.
You feel trapped with these people who have allowed their lives to become mundane hells and for some reason are forcing you to share it with them.
Elegant, creepy, but a little too faithful to the original.
Go in with low expectations and be willing to catch a few good, surprising things amid the standard-level drama you already saw coming.
Even darker and weirder and more cynical than Kick-Ass.
Dozens of ideas and pastiches from other films, none of which fit comfortably into this small-town melodrama.
A more admirable movie than a lovable one, but director Mark Romanek has so faithfully adapted Ishiguro's novel with such grace that it's moving in its own quiet way.
Broader, bigger and more traditional than Boden and Fleck's previous work-- and unfortunately, significantly less successful.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With a sure hand both behind and in front of the camera, Aselton exposes a raw nerve within all of us, and even entertains in the process.
127 Hours combines the power of cinema with a great story to terrify us and move us in equal measure. Said simply, it's wonderful.
A fantastic exploration of the struggles of women in a world run by men.
A totally delightful original.
A great pleasure to watch, and a terrific first feature from Winkler.
A portrait of the generational hero no one asked for, the world he changed by accident, and all the things his invention will never change no matter how hard we try.
It's enough to make me give up on Heigl.
Red starts to devolve into nonsense well before it takes advantage of the many things it has going for it.

Alfredson is merely interested in repeating the highlights, recreating the best moments of the book but also the worst, resulting in a film that hits with precision as often as it seems to drag endlessly.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Monogamy is surprising for how well it tackles themes we thought had been fully examined on film.
Probably the only Western set in northern Scotland, and that must count for something.
Nearly everyone involved in Paul has been part of some kind of comedic masterpiece, which may be why I can't help wishing this perfectly good movie had gotten a little closer to being great.
A blast of imagination and wit and sheer nerve, an alien invasion movie twice as entertaining as the ones Hollywood has churned out all summer, made at a fraction of the cost.
A funny and fast-paced blast of silly energy, willfully dumb with a clever streak that keeps it afloat just long enough.
Bungles everything that's basically appealing about concerts, movies, 3D technology and even the TV show Glee itself.
Farrell and Tennant are the best reason to see a movie that's sometimes more trying than fun.
Where Moon was a marvel of restraint and working within limits, Source Code suffers from a scale no one seems able to control.
It's a shame to see Rudd given a role that lets him hit it out of the park in a movie that never comes close to matching him.
Aside from a handful of raunchy jokes and a lot of nudity, though, A Good Old Fashioned Orgy plays it too safe.
The rare kind of thriller that's even more interesting below the surface.
Even if Warrior could have or should have shaped up into something bigger, it's impossible not to recommend.
Contagion is satisfying and spooky and a total thrill to watch.
Something new and thrumming with life, a movie about detachment that has an intoxicating staying power.
Full of punchy energy and a sense of catharsis about getting away from all the stupid places pop culture can take us.
It has a big, open heart .
The movie is occasionally moving and very well-acted, but despite all the crying manages to feel slight.
A Dangerous Method feels drained of meaning and artistic intent.
Passionate And remarkable.
There's a much smarter, better constructed movie in there that could have better used the dynamite cast.
A film that's as moving as it is witty and dark. It's simply terrific.
A fantastic performance from Kiefer Sutherland.
Brad Pitt anchors it with a performance that might be the best he's ever given as a leading man.
It's not the strongest Shakespeare play in the world, but it's a striking adaptation well worth a look.
A story that goes everywhere you expect it to go, and nowhere worth going at all.
Lautner appears as stiff and confused as a middle-school kid caught unprepared in the school play.
There's no real conflict built within the story, no villains or obstacles to root against other than the general foes of warlords and death.
See it, goggle at its strangeness, marvel at how a movie can be haunting even when it doesn't work at all.
Another regrettable entry in the ongoing Hollywood saga of "When bad movies happen to good people."
It's frustrating to see talent, money and time poured into a project that's just a pale, pointless imitation of something that's already perfectly great on its own.
See it for Olsen's breakthrough performance and Durkin's keen cinematic eye.
Completely impossible to understand, a dumb movie that makes you feel dumb.
Throwing every style of comedy and romantic complication at the wall to see what sticks, the filmmakers find out too late that almost none of it does.
Neither a Western nor an alien film, really, just another Hollywood blockbuster massaged and pruned within an inch of its life.
It's a talky book translated into a talky movie that's sometimes more clever than it is effective.
Deathly Hallows Part 2 isn't just a proper sendoff, but maybe the best argument for adapting these books to film in the first place.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Win Win isn't aiming for anything grand or life-altering, but sometimes it's almost better to see a simple and resonant story told so well.
McConaughey is the definition of a movie star here, sitting back and allowing his charm to imbue the entire film.
This is a movie convinced that a rabbit pooping jelly beans is the height of comedy.
Odd, scatterbrained and sometimes a little too clever, but it's also passionate and captivating, combining a coming-of-age tenderness with heart-stopping action in a way that feels utterly unique.
A movie of easily digestible truths and canned inspirational messages, taking every possible easy route though a story that could have used a few more thorns.
Gerwig doesn't single-handedly save the movie but she does seem to have a calming influence on those around her, bringing out the best particularly in Brand and Mirren.
Musty and stagy in a way that guarantees it will bore generations of high school students on movie day.
Briskly paced and very funny, The Future sneaks up on you with its weight, landing a series of devastating punches near the end that also don't belie the film's witty assessment of human faults.
A beach read of a movie, broad and unchallenging but spirited and sometimes moving too. It's the kind of froth just strong enough to sweep you up if you'll allow it.
Artistic growth is nothing compared to pleasing his built-in audience with the same sap and slapstick they've paid for nine times before.
As confident and charismatic as its lead characters and every bit as fun to be around.
It's one thing to make a mediocre film that panders to children, but another to post-convert the entire thing into unnecessary 3D, twisting the knife even further.
A movie that sidesteps cynicism and its own sloppy script to become a perfectly good, perfectly scaled bit of summer entertainment.
Kate Hudson has punished us yet again.
The best Scream since the original.
Enjoyable and funny and lovely to look at, not all we could ask from Allen, but the kind of fanciful and well-acted movie he still does better than anybody.
On Stranger Tides is neither the best nor worst way to keep the Pirates of the Caribbean money flowing, but it always feels like a franchised product.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Horrible Bosses is entertaining and brazen, a clear reminder that to make a good comedy, all you've really gotta do is make it funny.
As a tween dream spin on Roman Holiday by way of Twelfth Night, it does its job quite nicely.
Tucker and Dale has no ambitions beyond entertaining; luckily it's pretty good at it.
Michael Bay uses the 3D almost miraculously well, achieving real moments of vertigo with the extra dimension.
Freddie Highmore became famous as a child actor in films like Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, but he's thoroughly unprepared for the challenges of an adult leading role.
Zookeeper is exactly as loud and sloppy as you expected it to be, livened only occasionally by James and some of his co-stars mugging from inside the muck.
See it for the air conditioning and cheap babysitting, but stay for a shred of surprising charm.
Even 30 years from now, though, Page One will remain a vital and fascinating portrait of the news and the people who make it.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A soulless and badly unfunny retread of everything that worked the first time.
Tree of Life is a gobsmacking experience that earns its grandness.
Tower Heist isn't aggressively bad or even offensive, but its utter lack of presence is almost worse.
Super 8 is a blast to watch, that kind of well-oiled summer entertainment that both surprises you and gives you exactly what you want.
At this point in the superhero genre the same old origin story simply isn't enough.
A blast of colorful and passionate enthusiasm with just enough weight to matter.
Things just weren't as fun this time around.
... the film only leaves you with a few great moments, but they're hard to cling to when surrounded by a story that lacks the proper substance.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sing mostly just checks the boxes, and maybe does enough to be an okay film.
The Space Between Us certainly had potential. However, it fails to reach the same lengths its very characters already had.
Survival is human nature. But what happens after that? Belko leaves that up to its audience, but with little evidence to try and make a decent argument.

There's better horror out there. There's better horror-comedy out there, too. What it all really comes down to, though, is if there's going to be another Groundhog Day film attempt, there has to be a better justification for it.
Justice League lightens up the DCEU, so at least this time, there was some fun to be had.
If apocalypse stories are your thing, don't miss out on I Think We're Alone Now.
Even if the film meanders a bit in the beginning, the wait is worth the final product.
Blindspotting succeeds in the smaller moments more so than with the bigger picture.

But it's still the same old shenanigans, catchphrases, pop culture references, and lightning fast dialogue that once made Psych so much fun to watch. Psych: The Movie is a pleasant, comforting return.
A confident starting point for Dano's directorial career, it will leave you looking forward for more of his sure to be eclectic career behind the camera.
The story's beautiful packaging doesn't make up for the way it has been commercialized.
The Hollars is a great little indie that really has it all.
Natalie Portman's first directed film turned into a beautiful piece of art, honoring a brilliant memoir and important time in history.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With the power of storytelling, Reichardt shows us the absolute power of being human.

Ultimately, however, the movie disappoints...Even with the heartbreak, the Madoffs don't quite make for sympathetic characters. Their riches, privilege, and apparent obliviousness to Bernie's epic deceit prove too much to get past.
To watch this film is to sublimate my Western context for how love should be found, and instead open my mind to the way that 1.3 billion people on Earth might choose to do it.
Dark and twisted, with sexually suggestive undercurrents, this one's as safe to miss as a sunburn by the club poolside.
Likable performances, but the story's brash and hyper, though sweet, delivery grows wearing, especially the sexual innuendo.
There is a distinct pleasure in watching a rising star make a cad of himself.
If you're looking for action-adventure, director Peter Berg has delivered in terms of explosiveness, but not with character development.
This movie is sharp. It makes you think.
For all its eye-catching design, however, Pan sorely lacks a much-needed sense of wonderment, and by focusing its efforts on the outlandish it forgets to be playful.
Essentially this sequel is far too preoccupied with boobs, stroking the male ego and crass, old-fashioned jokes to deliver anything engaging or truly witty.
A thoroughly engaging and involving - albeit tough - viewing experience. Barrett's strong second feature marks him out as one to watch.

Two by Two delivers a few decent jokes and should be enough to keep very young children amused, but there's nothing truly original in its telling and its extreme predictability may prove painfully testing to parents.
movie_title: All Creatures Big and Small (Ooops! Noah is Gone...) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Though some of the plot doesn't entirely add up, with a few ill thought-out reveals towards the end, the sinister atmosphere is enough to keep you teetering on the edge of your seat for most of the running time.
Despite Wyrmwood never quite matching up to the films it emulates, it's often ingenious, with a passion for the sub-genre that's genuinely infectious.
This accessible and heartfelt anime charms because of its honesty and impressive attention [to] detail.
The heady thrills of nostalgia power this spectacular looking ride along and it's a lot of fun while it lasts.
The enjoyably knowing flavour of the original is still present but feels strangely diluted in this sequel.
An achingly beautiful, tightly wound package of woe that slowly comes undone over the course of its running time to reveal something very special indeed.
This sharply observed, utterly magical coming-of-age story has a beautiful message for everyone, not just kids.
Careers and love collide in this cathartic New York-set sing-a-long session that relishes both life's highs and lows, only occasionally hitting bum notes.
Villeneuve (Enemy, Prisoners) sticks close to thriller formula but also takes the path less travelled along the way.
A whimsical hand-drawn animation concerned with the woes of consumerism that wonderfully embraces the mischievous spirit of its eccentric Finnish creator.
Slaboshpytskiy has stated that, 'It's been my dream to pay homage to the silent movie,' and the result is a relentlessly bleak and brutal coming-of-age drama that makes for mesmerising viewing.
The DUFF is a heartfelt film that adheres somewhat to formula, but that's distinguished by its knowingness, Josh A Cagan's smart script and by a riotous central performance from Whitman.
Satrapi's bold, bright and entertaining creation is laced with a pitch-black, sometimes truly sick sense of humour; it's wrong on many levels but that's also what makes it so right.
The real problem here lies with the underwritten supporting characters and overabundance of repetitive action sequences.
This enchanting, admirable fable will elicit exuberant joy and great sadness due to the fact that it both celebrates women and mourns the limitations of their life under patriarchy.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is a rare filmmaker who can effortlessly glide between so many different psyches in such an insightful and witty way.
A charming, utterly lovely and brilliantly acted coming-of-ager.
A supernatural horror brought to you by Michael Bay and Hasbro and released just in time for Halloween proves just as soulless as you might imagine it to be.
It's at its most poignant and engaging when it comes to family matters, but loses points on the superheroics front.

This admirable misfire is often endearing and Chappie is creatively designed and feels real, but an unsophisticated approach to its subject matter combined with the slight characterisations edges it perilously close to the scrapheap.
Appropriate Behaviour is a confident and witty debut about finding yourself and fitting in that knows exactly what it wants to say. Akhavan is undoubtedly one to watch.
Eden is celebratory, cautionary and entirely intoxicating.
Peter Strickland's sumptuous, all-female S&M fable is the director's greatest film to date.
It's a unique, funny and ultimately crushing descent into the deep well of loneliness, that cannily blurs the lines between fantasy and reality.
Like a cross between the best parts of Educating Yorkshire and the worst parts of The X Factor, with it delivering a few questionable moments among the many highlights.
It plays out like a convoluted mix of The Princess Diaries meets The Fifth Element, with the siblings blending an overabundance of sci-fi premises and visuals.
With his charming second feature, writer-director-producer Uberto Pasolini has created a potent and poignant exploration of love and death, solitude and the breakdown of community.

For the most part, Sponge Out of Water provides decent-sized doses of wacky animated fun; it's packed full of hilarious one-liners, pop culture references and colourful characters that should keep both adults and kids entertained.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chapter 3 in the Insidious franchise is an improvement on the second film but it's nowhere near as polished as the original.

Matt Reeves, the director of another end of the world type scenario in found footage film Cloverfield, takes the reins of this smart and attractive franchise and runs confidently with visceral wanton destruction and a blunt message about gun control.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Years of filming, research and gaining trust pay off impressively in this terrifying, tense and essential documentary.
This is Robert Eggers' first feature and it's a knockout in terms of visual flair and dread-filled potency.
A heartbreaking, profound and tremblingly taut experience, that plays almost as an upside down version of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland ...
Exploring the burgeoning bond between a 70-year-old widower and a young businesswoman allows for some delightful and amusing observations about our ever-changing world.
Not even the mighty Toni Collette can save this.
Solace is mildly entertaining in bursts ... but clichÃ©s thwart it for the most part and the final twist can be seen coming from a mile off.
Dartmoor Killing is not without merit, but the shallow handling of serious issues including the repression of a tragic incident mars it somewhat.
Strong attention to detail and a disquieting score set this debut feature apart, but some of the characters' motivations aren't entirely convincing.
The Visit is crass and predictable, and nearly as bad as the extremely dire The Happening.
The Second Mother strikes a passionate moral chord that also connects with conversations about the importance of achieving social change through cross-generational education.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Although it sometimes veers into off-putting caricature, American Ultra revels in the amusing bewilderment that comes when a couple of star-crossed slackers are thrust into a violent situation, with the dry one-liners proving very quotable.
Despite the screenplay's crafty curve-balls there's still a distinct sense of dÃ©jÃ  vu as each thread is drawn together, while an unconvincing police slip-up is inserted to help drag the story out.
Despite it following a corny narrative and featuring some odd directorial decisions, especially in the final throes, We Are Your Friends is charmingly sincere ...
Another bittersweet film about boys growing up and demystifying women that disappointingly short-changes its female characters.
A light and fluffy lampooning of both the middle classes and the male gaze, featuring a great performance from the ever-charming Gemma Arterton in the title role.
Though Trainwreck struggles with its structure - occasionally feeling like a sketch show - it's certainly honest, though perhaps to a fault.
A strange departure into slapstick renders any genuine sentiment null and void and the balance between comedy and drama is just never properly gaged.
An overly sentimental, ham-fisted family drama ...
Matteo Garrone's stunning intertwining trilogy of macabre and peculiar fairy tales is brought to breathtaking life by a precise and painterly hand.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Trash possesses a hopeful nature, which is fine, but its decision to brush over dangerous situations with easy answers just doesn't sit right.
Despite its slick appearance, this reboot ends up being a disappointing, watered-down mess devoid of its own identity.
[A] juvenile and, apparently, intentionally crappy final outing that has nothing insightful to add to an already overstretched idea.
An ambitious and striking effort.
Moore imbues a warm sensibility and honesty to this fantasy adventure that doesn't shy away from its serious themes.
Kudos has to be given to Hartley for lifting the lid on a host of bad practices and making an honest documentary that could so easily have been turned into a juvenile exercise in macho backslapping.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A charming and eccentric heist film with a great sense of humour.

X-Men: Days of Future Past is convoluted and some of it doesn't make sense but it's a complete blast from start to finish thanks to a fine cast, good sense of humour and Fassbender spouting James Brown lyrics at random.
Add a split screen montage sequence that uses solid black lines for separation in true 60s style, saucy banter and some self referential wit and you have a solid piece of stylish filmmaking.
There's lots of fun to be had with a train-top fight, allowing Wolverine to show off those adamantium claws, and snow-set Ninja battles, but the final sequence feels messy.
The Lobster is as weird and wonderful as it sounds and will make you think twice before asking the dreaded question, 'Are you still single?'
Approaches high-concept sci-fi with a serious-mind, but also shoe-horns in banal moments of broad entertainment, making it a difficult pill to swallow.

Intense action and emotion make for gripping viewing and along with a dash of playfulness that occasionally lifts the dark mood it feels like the comic book hero has been rightly adapted for our times.

The latest in a long line of found-footage horror movies that comes with the neat premise of a high school haunting, but that bumps around in the dark for far too long with no sense of where it's going.
Broomfield and editors Joe Bini and Marc Hoeferlin construct their film like a maddening and gripping episode of Columbo.
This is a thematically rich psychological thriller which examines identity, responsibility and desire and sets out to disorientate and perplex.
Robespierre is reaching out to other women about the value of sharing our experiences in this weighty and hilarious comedy.
Sexual fantasies and the stuff of nightmares come together in this disorientating, provocative and exquisitely crafted journey through 1970s Euro-horror and sexploitation.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film festival hangover is pondered in this well observed but somewhat slight French comedy, which nails the snubbing and superficiality of the industry.
A meaty thriller/horror blend which delves deep into the male psyche and the effect military service has had on the population of Israel. Tense and brutal with a macabre sense of humour.
An unimaginative and humourless dark comedy from French director Luc Besson, starring Robert De Niro who appears to be phoning his lines in.
One Chance tells the story of Paul Potts in a sweet and over sentimental way veering away from the truth in favour of the usual formulaic Hollywood style story.
Johnny Knoxville revives his old man character, Irving Zisman, for another crude and audacious comedy that's actually quite funny.
[A] sincere and heartening American indie set in short term accommodation for displaced children.
An amusing and crowd pleasing selection of found footage from a group of up and coming genre directors with one deeply disturbing stand out section from Gareth Evans and Timo Tjahjanto.
A mean and refreshing addition to the American indie quarter life crisis genre, shot on black and white 35mm film, and composed entirely of mobile phone calls.
movie_title: I Play With The Phrase Each Other (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A uniquely peculiar and hilarious piece of indie cinema, that plays like an American Withnail and I, with added central characters.
A harrowing, important and shocking documentary which tells the story of Shin Dong-Hyuk who was born into captivity in a North Korean death camp in 1983.
An inspiring and compelling documentary about the risks of extreme sports with a focus on snowboarder Kevin Pearce.
A surreal and haunting exploration of grief and superstition, set in a small Scottish fishing village amidst a tragic shipwreck with a lone survivor.
An exhilarating and immersive Metallica concert film twinned with a dark, trippy narrative following a roadie named Trip who pops a pill and goes on a mission to find a mysterious package.
A playful Polanski serves up a rich and provocative discourse on sexual politics and gender bias with this pithy and extremely witty two-hander bolstered by the exceptional leads.
Slavoj Zizek psychoanalyses cinema and society in this engaging, interesting and spirited documentary.
A provocative and poetic piece of filmmaking from Polish Director Malgorzata Szumowska which follows a priest as he struggles to find peace between his sexual desires and religious vows.

Craig Scott Rosebraugh delivers an informative if somewhat self-satisfied expose of climate change deniers, explaining exactly where they get their funding from and how they are determined to dupe the public despite the devastating consequences.

An involving and important drama which provides excellent insight into the life of political theorist Hannah Arendt during the time she reported on the Adolf Eichmann trial, only sadly marred by some bad acting and poor dialogue.
A bland and unsophisticated crime thriller set in the world of online gambling which sees Justin Timberlake and Ben Affleck go head to head and through the motions.
An engaging, intimate and illuminating look at music and style icon Adam Ant's current life and music career from filmmaker Jack Bond.
One of the biggest selling bands in the world, Def Leppard, gets the straightforward and strictly-for-fans filmed arena concert treatment for their Viva! Hysteria performance.
A fascinating, informative and startling documentary that explores the disappearance of the honeybee.
A passionate, creative and vibrant tribute to cultural theorist Stuart Hall that should inspire further discussion and reflection on the world we live in.
A vicious, unrelenting and bleak drama depicting the devastating effect of the current economic climate on society.
Museum Hours is a grand, profound and exceptionally beautiful love letter to museums and the wealth of culture that can be found in everyday life.
Funny, entirely relatable and beautifully shot slice of 1950s Calcutta life that centres around the dynamics of a middle-class family and the changing values of the time.
An engaging and touching drama about a young Turkish bride who moves to Austria as a second wife in a family who struggle to deal with her presence.
An extremely powerful documentary about Tibet's struggle for emancipation from China that's passionate in its plea and highly informative, although slightly bloated.
movie_title: When the Dragon Swallowed the Sun (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An immersive and creative appreciation of the Irish landscape, culture and language as shown by sound recordings of environments untouched by man-made noise, archive footage and frank dinner table discussion.
A playful and post-modern Argentinian comedy that lovingly mocks a grumpy old film critic and his aversion to the clichÃ©s of romantic Hollywood films.
It's undeniably enjoyable and ends up taking a surprising turn towards tackling societal issues, even if this does feel slightly manipulative.
The supporting stories are thin and the 3D is pointless but the dancing is, as ever, brilliant.
Gondry untamed is a visual genius.
A suspense-free step-down.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In keeping with his impressive body of work, acclaimed documentary filmmaker Steve James approaches the details of the life of film critic Roger Ebert with honesty and the utmost respect.
Big Eyes deserves kudos for exploring the symbiotic relationship between business and art and it feels very personal at times.

The middle section flags due to the relentless padding, yet the film features standout moments of spirited action and its most exhilarating battles bring to mind the greatness of the Lord of the Rings trio.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: GrÃ©gory Levasseur takes on directorial duties for the first time and though he ramps up tension at the final hurdle, for the most part this effort is hampered by a rote script from Daniel Meersand and Nick Simon.
Get Santa is an imaginative and madcap festive family film that has lots for both adults and kids to enjoy - think Porridge meets Elf.

Provides a raw reminder of how greedy capitalist culture has exploited a continent and its people, but it is also a passionate, proud and deeply affecting educational tool which puts forward a plan of action by tracing a passage through the past.
The heart of the film is in the right place and is a fun addition to the fantasy film genre.

An infectiously silly, frequently funny vampire mockumentary which is brought to life by a combination of impressive improvised dialogue, high-spirited performances and a keen knowledge of vampire mythology and motion pictures.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It may prove testing to short attention spans and coerced adults as it clocks in at an unnecessarily long 109 minutes, and that's mainly due to an annoyingly repetitive nature.
Ultimately this teen horror lacks any real hiss or bite.
Approaching the complexities of adult life and the strife of facing the past in such a shallow fashion dulls both the comedy and drama.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gia Coppola's debut about the teen experience has a lyricism that transcends James Franco's mediocre source.
The slickly choreographed fight scenes and shoot-outs are sped up and slowed down, making for exhilarating spectacle.
Suspenseful, atmospheric and spine-tingling horror cinema which nods at the masters and completely astounds as it manages the tough feat of being striking, sensitive and utterly disturbing.
Female anxieties and emotions spill over in a potent brew which effectively explores both sexual awakening and fear of the opposite sex.
Loss pierces every moment of this melancholy mystery where everyone appears to be frozen in time and evil lurks behind suburbia's respectable facade.
Even with all the misery MichÃ´d can't resist injecting some humour, which works well as a counterpoint to teasingly lighten the mood.
Ari Folman examines our relationship with cinema and takes a satirical swipe at Hollywood in this stunning and stimulating sci-fi fantasy which combines live action with animation.

The strong religious overtones are to be expected, but the way religion is depicted purely as a force for good comes across as distractingly preachy; it's a message delivered with all the nuance and balance of Fox News.

Underneath its comical surface lies a story about responsibility, parenting and a troubling history of neglect. With Housebound Johnstone asks his audience not to look the other way in the most intriguing and riotous way possible.
[An] incredibly tense two-hander which is hilarious and terrifying in equal parts.
The raw honesty which lies beneath this tale of loneliness, loss and coping mechanisms makes for emotionally impactful viewing, tinged with both sadness and hope.
Gleeson convinces as a desperate-to-please, ambitious young coder. Isaac's difficult-to-read, drunken, pumped-up mad scientist is disquieting and Vikander excels in a demure and shifting role.
A striking and menacing slow-burn thriller set in the Australian outback which blends dry humour with startling social commentary.

With references to Philip Marlowe and discussion of what it takes to make a good detective it's clear Frank intends Scudder to become a household name but, given this dodgy effort, that may never happen.
Draft Day ends up as the trashy, glitzy cousin to the Oscar-nominated Moneyball, minus the smart statistical hook.
A neatly packaged prequel which is better than it deserves to be thanks to a convincing performance from the aptly named Annabelle Wallis, and a couple of genuinely frightening set-pieces.
The Maze Runner moves at a reasonably enjoyable pace, taking us from CGI-heavy set-piece to set-piece and only occasionally stumbling.
An upbeat and smart British comedy set on a council estate in Peckham which follows two estranged brothers around for the day, as they search for some okra.
BjÃ¶rk's bizarre, beguiling vision is beautifully presented here; her dream-like musical ecosystem proving every bit as fascinating and inventive as the lady herself.
Pride is a warming, big-hearted affair which fully embraces the principles it so wonderfully portrays, turning itself into a lesson in compassion.
Diesel fails to convince in his role. His delivery is mostly flat and rarely do any of the one-liners hit their mark. It's a story of sorcery seriously lacking in cinematic magic.
There's a sweet message about friendship and self-love at the centre of it.
The writing team are focused on the juvenile, with gross-out gags galore, and the effects crew have a field day with some inventive blood spattering.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lipitz celebrates the enriching cross-generational relationships and the mother- daughter bonds, delivering an uplifting and beautiful documentary about the power of female solidarity.

Besson excels at driving home his message of the importance of unity while all appears to be crumbling around with a childlike enthusiasm that matches the giddy aesthetic. It's just a shame the surrounding story doesn't keep up with his vision.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If one's idea of a war movie is a cast of thousands amid big action and emotion then this might struggle to appeal, but it's a sombre, anxiety-inducing and welcome addition to the genre.
An indecently refreshing tonic of a film.
As the bloodthirsty sharks surround the women, Roberts creates a suffocating and terrifying atmosphere.
Though war is waged in exhilarating style, it is the strength of the characters' emotions that will leave you well and truly shaken.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Once you've seen Australian writer-director Ben Young's impressive debut, it's difficult to forget.
There's a compelling story to be told but Boom never pauses long enough to draw a complex portrait of the rapper raised by Black Panthers.
